>FORMER GERMAN CABINET MINISTER ATTACKS OFFICIAL BRAINWASHING ON
>SEPTEMBER 11 ISSUE
>[Source: Tagesspiegel, Berlin, Jan. 13] PARTIAL TRANSLATION
>
>In a full-page interview with the Sunday edition (Jan. 13) of the
>Berlin Tagesspiegel daily, former German Minister of Technology,
>Andreas von Buelow, said he does not buy any of the official theories
>that have been presented to date, on the events of September 11.
>
>Q: You seem so angry, really upset.
>
>Von Buelow: I can explain what's bothering me: I see that after the
>horrifying attacks of Sept. 11, all political public opinion is being
>forced into a direction that I consider wrong.
>
>Q: What do you mean by that?
>
>Von Buelow: I wonder why many questions are not asked. Normally, with
>such a terrible thing, various leads and tracks appear that are then
>commented on, by the investigators, the media, the government: Is
>there something here or not? Are the explanations plausible? This
>time, this is not the case at all. It already began just hours after
>the attacks in New York and Washington and--
>
>Q: In those hours, there was horror, and grief.
>
>Von Buelow: Right, but actually it was astounding: There are 26
>intelligence services in the U.S.A. with a budget of $30 billion--
>
>Q: ...more than the German defense budget...
>
>Von Buelow: --which were not able to prevent the attacks. In fact,
>they didn't even have an inkling they would happen. For 60 decisive
>minutes, the military and intelligence agencies let the fighter
>planes stay on the ground, 48 hours later, however, the FBI presented
>a list of suicide attackers. Within ten days, it emerged that seven
>of them were still alive.
>
>Q: What, please?
>
>Von Buelow: Yes, yes. And why did the FBI chief take no position
>regarding contradictions? Where the list came from, why it was false?
>If I were the chief investigator (state attorney) in such a case, I
>would regularly go to the public, and give information on which
>leadsare valid and which not.
>
>Q: That sounds like--
>
>Von Buelow: --like assailants who, in their preparations, leave
>tracks behind them like a herd of stampeding elephants? They made
>payments with credit cards with their own names; they reported to
>their flight instructors with their own names. They left behind
>rented cars with flight manuals in Arabic for jumbo jets. They took
>with them, on their suicide trip, wills and farewell letters, which
>fall into the hands of the FBI, because they were stored in the wrong
>place and wrongly addressed. Clues were left like behind like in a
>child's game of hide-and-seek, which were to be followed!
>
>There is also the theory of one British flight engineer: According to
>this, the steering of the planes was perhaps taken out ofthe pilots'
>hands, from outside. The Americans had developed a method in the
>1970s, whereby they could rescue hijacked planes by intervening into
>the computer piloting [automatic pilot system]. This theory says,
>this technique was abusedin this case. That's a theory....
>
>Q: Which sounds really adventurous, and was never considered.
>
>Von Buelow: You see! I do not accept this theory, but I find it worth
>considering. And what about the obscure stock transactions? In
>theweek prior to the attacks, the amount of transactions in stocks in
>American Airlines, United Airlines, and insurance companies,
>increased 1,200%. It was for a value of $15 billion. Some people must
>have known something. Who?
>
>Q: Why don't you speculate on who it might have been.
>
>Von Buelow: With the help of the horrifying attacks, the Western mass
>democracies were subjected to brainwashing. The enemy image of anti-
>communism doesn't work any more; it is to be replaced by peoples of
>Islamic belief. They are accused of having given birth to suicidal
>terrorism.
>
>Q: Brainwashing? That's a tough term.
>
>Von Buelow: Yes? But the idea of the enemy image doesn't come from
>me. It comes from Zbigniew Brzezinski and Samuel Huntington, two
>policy-makers of American intelligence and foreign policy. Already in
>the middle of he 1990s, Huntingon believed, people in Europe and
>theU.S. needed someone they could hate-- this would strengthen their
>identification with their own society. And Brzezinski, the mad dog,
>as adviser to President Jimmy Carter, campaigned for the exclusive
>right of the U.S. to seize all the raw materials of the world,
>especiallyoil and gas.
>
>Q: You mean, the events of Sept. 11--
>
>Von Buelow: --fit perfectly in the concept of the armaments industry,
>the intelligence agencies, the whole military-industrial-academic
>complex. This is in fact conspicuous. The huge raw materials reserves
>of the former Soviet Union are now at their disposal, also the
>pipeline routes and--
>
>Q: Erich Follach described that at length in Spiegel: ``It's amatter
>of military bases, drugs, oil and gas reserves.''
>
>Von Buelow: I can state: the planning of the attacks was technically
>and organizationally a master achievement. To hijack four huge
>airplanes within a few minutes and within one hour, to drive them
>into their targets, with complicated flight maneuvers! This is
>unthinkable, without years-long support from secret apparatuses of
>the state and industry.
>
>Q: You are a conspiracy theorist!
>
>Von Buelow: Yeah, yeah. That's the ridicule heaped [on those raising
>these questions] by those who would prefer to follow the official,
>politically correct line. Even investigative journalists are fed
>propaganda and disinformation. Anyone who doubts that, doesn't have
>all his marbles! That is your accusation.
>
>Q: Your career actually speaks against the idea that you are not in
>your right mind. You were already in the 1970s, state secretary in
>theDefense Ministry; in 1993 you were the SPD [Social Democratic
>Party] speaker in the Schalk-Golodkowski investigation committee--
>
>Von Buelow: And it all began there! Until that time, I did not have
>any great knowledge of the work of intelligence agencies. And now we
>had to take note of a great discrepancy: We shed light on the
>dealings of the Stasi and other East bloc intelligence agencies in
>the field of economic criminality, but as soon as we wanted to know
>something about the activities of the BND [German intelligence
>agency] or the CIA, it was mercilessly blocked. No information, no
>cooperation, nothing! That's when I was first taken aback.
>
>
>Not at war. ----- "On the surface, selling arms to a country that
>sponsors terrorism, of course, clearly, you'd have to argue it's
>wrong, but it's the exception sometimes that proves the rule." -
>George Bush on Good Morning America. 01/28/87
>
>




New Brunswick Peoples Campaign 2002
Unite the Many, Defeat the Few!

Free The Land

To the consciously free in heart and mind, I write to you today on behalf of 
the Queens 2.  Bashir Hameed and Abdul Majid collectively known as the 
Queens 2 have been imprisoned since the early 1980�s in New York State.  
Abdul and Bashir have the distinction of having been tried three times by 
the state of New York.  Their first trial ended in a hung jury, the second 
in a mistrial and the third in a conviction.   Currently, the Queens 2 have 
a pending appeal in the eastern district of New York pertaining to a 
violation of their constitutional rights.  In their final trial the district 
attorney used 14 of their 20 votes to remove Black people from the jury 
pool.

do so. An updated and revised version of their story is about to be 
published. This booklet will be used as a fundraiser, circulated

need for people to contribute whatever they can to the production of this 
booklet.  All donations can be made out to:  Malcolm X Grassroots Movement,

In Love & Struggle,
Malcolm X Grassroots Movement

Post ID:2540
Sender:Dwayne Middleton <nia7@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-02-01 20:14:07
Subject:Ras Baraka 2002 Headquarters Kickoff!!!!
Message:

Please join the Committee to Elect Ras Baraka to the opening of the
campaign headquarters!!!
*************************************************************************

Date:            Saturday, February 2, 2002

Location:       350-70 W. Market Street
                    Newark, NJ

Time:            4:00 pm
*************************************************************************

              For more information, please call (973) 242-0522.

                       Donations gladly accepted!!!

Frequently Asked Questions about the Ras Baraka Campaign for
Council-At-Large
(Newark, NJ)

Q1. Why are you running for Council-At-Large?

I'm running so that resources of public office can be better used for
working families and so that resources are redistributed into the hands
of the people. I also want to ensure that Newark's Renaissance means a
citywide rebirth, not just downtown.

Q2.  What are the main things you'd like to see changed in Newark?

Education, employment, and recreation.   I'm currently a Vice Principal
in Newark and before
that I was a public school teacher in this city for 10 years. I believe
that we need to return to
local control of our school system. I also believe that we need to raise
standards in the
classrooms by offering advanced courses and 'state of the art'
technology and resources.

On employment: while there are a mere 1,000 jobs available for our
youth this summer, we watch the tragedy of car thefts and gang
recruitment.  Newark's Renaissance must translate into more jobs for
city residents. Everyone is
entitled to a job that pays a living wage. Employment not only  provides
income and keeps our
kids out of trouble, but it gives
dignity as well.

On recreation: it needs to be meaningful, structured, and it
should  involve the entire family. Recreation just doesn't mean sports,
it includes dance, theater, computers, art, literature, trips, etc. and
can be an effective approach in developing our community - culturally
and
socially.

Q3. What are your views on crime and the police in Newark?

I know residents are concerned with the proliferation of drugs on our
streets and the growing amount of gang activity. I also share these
concerns. I am opposed to all forms of crime - be it committed by
civilians or by the police.
Education, employment, and recreation can reduce crime. Until
then,  there should be a visible level of community policing. Also, the
police should be controlled by the community, not by politicians or
police fraternities.

Q4. What do you think are your strongest assets for this position?

I have been a community activist for about 15 years, meaning that
I've been very engaged in the lives of the people of Newark. They
respect me
because of my respect for them. On top of that, I graduated from Howard
University with a Bachelor's degree in Political Science & History. I
also have a Master's in
Education from St. Peters College in Jersey City.

Q5. What are your long-term political objectives? And when is the actual
election?

My only objective is to win a seat for the people of Newark. The
election is  May 2002.

          TIME TO TAKE IT PERSONAL!!!!!!!!!!!

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign urges folks to read and forward out this 
quick update on the case of Pedro Colon Almenas.  This text was translated 
from Spanish to English by proLibertad.  This update comes from Pedro Colon 
Almenas' support committee in Puerto Rico.

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
www.ProLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244
_______________________________________________________________________

Last Sept. 10th, Pedro Colon Almenas, a student and member of the Union de 
Juventudes Socialistas and the Movimiento Socialista de Trabajdores, was 
found guilty of "Aggravated Assualt against a Military Officer" by Judge 
Hector Lafitte (an ex-JAG Lawyer, pro-navy advocate, who has made it his 
goal to punish all activists who have done civil disobedience in Vieques 
with absurd sentences).  Pedro sentencing which was first scheduled for Jan. 
22nd, has been postponed to Friday February 22nd, 2002.  Pedro could face up 
to five years in jail.  Pedro is a graduate student who has been a powerful 
student leader.  His only "crime" has been to fight for a University of 
Puerto Rico without a military/ROTC presence on it, and for demanding that 
the U.S. Navy leave Vieques.  It is important that all communites become 
aware of Pedro's case; He is a victim of a sham trial and a colonial 
government intent on jailing activists that work against the colonial status 
quo.

It is important that people check out  http://www.bander.org/pedro/  the 
site is back up and the information is in Spanish.

>IMPORTANT GREEN PARTY EVENTS IN MARCH AND APRIL
>
>
>Event #1: Petition Drive Kick-off for NJ Green Campaign 2002
>
>Date: Saturday, March 9    11:00am to 2:00pm
>Location: Rutgers Labor Education Center, Room 115
>
>The Greens expect to be fielding one of our most extensive slates this 
>year, running candidates for national, state, county, and municipal 
>offices.  Among others, GPNJ Chair Joseph Fortunato will be running for 
>U.S. Congress and Vice Chair Jane Hunter will be running for council in her 
>home town of Bound Brook.  We are still soliciting candidates, and we hope 
>all locals will encourage one or several of their members to step forward 
>to take the Green Party message to the voters in some capacity next fall.
>
>In our highest-visibility race this year Ted Glick, National Coordinator of 
>the Independent Progressive Politics Network, will be the Green Party 
>candidate challenging for the U.S. Senate seat currently held by Robert 
>Torricelli.  Ted has been a prominent activist for decades and has 
>participated in a wide range of struggles -- such that we expect his 
>candidacy to resonate among peace, environment, labor, minority, and other 
>social change activists all across the state.  To show the extent of 
>support for this campaign we'd like to submit more petition signatures than 
>we've ever done before.  As Greens and supporters hit the streets this 
>spring to gather signatures for local candidates (all petitions must be 
>submitted by the first week of June) we will be encouraging everyone to 
>carry a clipboard with a Glick for Senate petition.
>
>Please join us March 9 to meet our candidates and discuss strategy for NJ 
>Green Campaign 2002!
>
>
>Event #2: GPNJ Sixth Annual Convention
>
>Date: Sunday, April 28    9:00am to 4:30pm
>Location: Rutgers Labor Education Center, Main Auditorium
>
>The Green Party has emerged as New Jersey's leading alternative party.  Our 
>bedrock principles of nonviolence, grassroots democracy, social justice, 
>and environmental protection have never been more relevant than in this 
>period of national crisis and apprehension.
>
>The Annual Convention is a time for members to make their voices heard on 
>the variety of issues that face our party, to sign up to participate on 
>statewide committees, to modify the organizational bylaws, and to elect 
>party officers.  Non-members are welcome to join us as observers--check out 
>this dynamic new party and learn about the international movement for Green 
>politics.  An extensive collection of Green Party literature will be 
>available.
>
>
>So save the dates!  Join us March 9 and April 28 in New Brunswick!
>

This is an invite to all the organizations and individuals that work with or 
support ProLibertad and the Malcom X Grassroots Movement...

Solidarity folks,

This is Benjamin Ramos of the ProLibertad Freedom Campaign, I am sending 
this email out as an invitation and inquiry for endorsement for a very 
special activity that is coming up on March 9th.  On Saturday March 9th, The 
Malcom X Grassroots movement and ProLibertad are putting together a special 
forum on the Patriot Act and how it effects our organizing in communities.

Kamau Franklin, of MXGM, will be putting together a panel of lawyers that 
will address the issues of immigration, FBI repression and a basic "What is 
the Patriot Act?" analysis.  It will be held at Hunter College West building 
6th floor room 615 from 1pm-3pm, e68th St. and Lexington Avenue.

This forum's goal is to educate  the community around the new legislation 
and how it will and has already effected our anti war work, our political 
prisoner work, our anti-imperialism, and immigration work.  It is shocking 
that many in all our communities (especially the people of color activist 
community) are unaware of the new blatantly repressive/pro-facist 
legislation that has become common law.

I invite you all to the forum, but more importantly I ask you to endorse 
this forum.  Please lend your organizations' name and promotional resources 
for this event.  I ask that if you endorse the forum that you get the flyer 
and mobilize your organization and its constituents to come it out.  We ask 
you to send out the info. to your email lists, to send out the flyers in 
your mailings and to adversitse the activity on any media sources you have 
access to as well.

We need to build this forum and get our communities educated.  We are in a 
repressive time and we must be informed.  Our work and security are at 
stake.  Let us fill those seats with our communities.

Please email me ( uriyoan@... ) with your organizational endorsement 
and to ask for the flyer.  An endorsement list will also be sent with the 
flyer.  This list will be constantly be updated until March 9th, 2002.

Subject:nb murals
Message:



               Tammy Paolino: Mural projects give vision of city life 
through the eyes of their artists

               Published in the Home News Tribune 2/16/02

               I have lots of favorite things to do in Philadelphia.

               I love to take in a folk show at the Tin Angel, for instance. 
I also love to go to the Vet and watch the Yankees whoop the Phils, and 
maybe even grab a late-night cheesesteak at Pat's Steaks.

               When in Philly, I enjoy a visit to the Rodin Museum, shopping 
in Manyunk, a leisurely brunch with the bo-hos at the Morning Glory, or a 
rainy afternoon browsing at Tower Records.

               While I'm doing all of that, I have another favorite thing to 
do -- checking out the murals that adorn the brick faces and exposed walls 
of buildings throughout the City of Brotherly Love.

               All over town, larger-than-life images of historical figures, 
professional athletes, ballerinas and jazz musicians, hot-house flowers, 
geometric abstractions, and, these days, especially, bursts of patriotism, 
loom above the taxis and minivans and buses and huddled masses that fill the 
streets.

               Philadephia's murals are a result of The Mural Arts Project, 
a program administered by the city's recreation department. In addition to 
beautification, the projects' goals are to eliminate "graffiti vandalism" 
and to "(expand) educational visual arts opportunities throughout the 
Philadelphia region."

               Through the program, artists and kids - including some of 
those interested in graffiti art and spray cans -- work together to create 
art in public spaces throughout the city.

               Here at home, murals can be found in some downtown areas -- 
including several colorful works scattered around downtown New Brunswick. In 
March, for instance, the Hungarian-American Athletic Club on Somerset Street 
offered a wall of its building for a mural dedicated to the Bristol-Myers 
Squibb Children's Hospital at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital.

               New Brunswick has so much to celebrate -- what with its rich 
ethnic diversity, its proximity to the river and the D&R canal, its 
reputation as a cultural center for the arts and, of course, its growing 
prominence as a leader in medical research and health care.

               Murals are an enduring and dramatic way to pay tribute to 
civic leaders and local heroes, recall historical events, encourage civic  
pride, or just add some urban charm to an otherwise drab section of town.

               The People's Community Arts Mural Project of New Brunswick 
has several public mural projects planned throughout the city. CAMP 
volunteers -- artists, community leaders, students and others interested in 
sprucing things up -- work weekends on mural
projects in the area. (Those interested in picking up a paint brush can 
contact Tamara Dahan at tamaradahan@... or Maura Carey at 
mauracarey@...)

               Collaborative public art projects are meant to bring diverse 
groups of people together in an ongoing conversation about their vision of 
their neighborhood, their city and their world.

               While the Mural Project is likely to benefit from the many 
talented artists and art students from the New Brunswick and Rutgers 
University communities, the program will have an even greater impact on the 
city if members of lots of other groups get involved as well.

               It's my hope, for instance, that the graffiti artists 
currently showcasing their talents in the cavernous tunnels and on the 
towering bridges along Route 18 will grab their spray cans, come into the 
light and make their marks where they will really count.

               Tammy Paolino's column appears every Saturday. (732) 
565-7330. E-mail tpaolino@...

               from the Home News Tribune

               Published: February 16, 2002






unite the many, defeat the few!

Tammy Paolino: Mural projects give vision of city life
through the eyes of their artists

Published in the Home News Tribune 2/16/02

I have lots of favorite things to do in Philadelphia.

I love to take in a folk show at the Tin Angel, for instance. I also love to 
go to the Vet and watch the Yankees whoop the Phils, and maybe even grab a 
late-night cheesesteak at Pat's Steaks.

When in Philly, I enjoy a visit to the Rodin Museum, shopping
in Manyunk, a leisurely brunch with the bo-hos at the Morning Glory, or a 
rainy afternoon browsing at Tower Records.

While I'm doing all of that, I have another favorite thing to do -- checking 
out the murals that adorn the brick faces and exposed walls of buildings 
throughout the City of Brotherly Love.

All over town, larger-than-life images of historical figures, professional 
athletes, ballerinas and jazz musicians, hot-house flowers, geometric 
abstractions, and, these days, especially, bursts of patriotism, loom above 
the taxis and minivans and buses and huddled masses that fill the streets.

Philadephia's murals are a result of The Mural Arts Project, a program 
administered by the city's recreation department. In addition to 
beautification, the projects' goals are to eliminate "graffiti vandalism" 
and to "(expand) educational visual arts opportunities throughout the 
Philadelphia region."

Through the program, artists and kids - including some of those interested 
in graffiti art and spray cans -- work together to create art in public 
spaces throughout the city.

Here at home, murals can be found in some downtown areas -- including 
several colorful works scattered around downtown New Brunswick. In March, 
for instance, the Hungarian-American Athletic Club on Somerset Street 
offered a wall of its building for a mural dedicated to the Bristol-Myers 
Squibb Children's Hospital at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital.

New Brunswick has so much to celebrate -- what with its rich ethnic 
diversity, its proximity to the river and the D&R canal, its reputation as a 
cultural center for the arts and, of course, its growing prominence as a 
leader in medical research and health care.

Murals are an enduring and dramatic way to pay tribute to civic leaders and 
local heroes, recall historical events, encourage civic pride, or just add 
some urban charm to an otherwise drab section of town.

The People's Community Arts Mural Project of New Brunswick has several 
public mural projects planned throughout the city. CAMP volunteers -- 
artists, community leaders, students and others interested in sprucing 
things up -- work weekends on mural projects in the area. (Those interested 
in picking up a paint brush can contact Tamara Dahan at 
tamaradahan@... or Maura Carey at
mauracarey@...)

Collaborative public art projects are meant to bring diverse groups of 
people together in an ongoing conversation about their vision of their 
neighborhood, their city and their world.

While the Mural Project is likely to benefit from the many talented artists 
and art students from the New Brunswick and Rutgers University communities, 
the program will have an even greater impact on the city if members of lots 
of other groups get involved as well.

It's my hope, for instance, that the graffiti artists currently showcasing 
their talents in the cavernous tunnels and on the towering bridges along 
Route 18 will grab their spray cans, come into the light and make their 
marks where they will really count.

Tammy Paolino's column appears every Saturday. (732)565-7330. E-mail 
tpaolino@...

                from the Home News Tribune

                Published: February 16, 2002


New Brunswick Peoples Campaign 2002

Post ID:2558
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-02-17 22:31:24
Subject:Re: [TheHubCityNJ] Make school board accountable to citizens
Message:

all the injuries inflicted on the community at the 1/15 board of ed mtg are 
'reprehensible'.  the issue is to fix responsibility on the antagonists.

but none of those 'reprehensible occurences' shd distract from the massive, 
daily 'reprehensible occurence' of nb's pitiful education record, to which 
we are all 'witness'.  for instance, the cut in funding suffered by the 
Puerto Rican Action Board's early childhood development center, at the hands 
of the un-elected board of education, which prefers to give public nb 
dollars to a private charter school and a private high school, over which 
the community has no democratic control.

there is no excuse whatever, given the vast wealth and education resources 
to be found in this city, why nb public school students shd not be provided 
the highest level of education imaginable. this despite the conspicuous (and 
likewise inexcusable) local poverty and related social degradation.  rather, 
it is most disingenuous to suggest eliminating these problems w/o first 
prioritizing education.

the public school board must be accountable, certainly to parents, but also 
to the entire community, as we are all affected in no small way by the 
success or failure of the education of nb's youth. or where do these 
children end up?

the connected issues of the 'taxation w/o representation' of nb's latino 
community, and nj's regressive tax structure, will also be resolved, like 
all social problems, only through more democracy, not less.

as we have seen, the elimination of democratic community control over 
newark's education system did nothing to eliminate 'patronage', 
'corruption', and lack of 'concern for the welfare of the students'.  to the 
contrary, the conditions there have worsened.

cliff

----Original Message Follows----
From: GUILLO@...
Reply-To: TheHubCityNJ@yahoogroups.com
To: TheHubCityNJ@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [TheHubCityNJ] Make school board accountable to citizens
Date: Sun, 17 Feb 2002 18:06:32 EST

I can't comment much on the incident at the BOE meeting for I was not a
witness; nevertheless it is my understanding that Police Chief Don Bowling
was bitten during a scuffle, a reprehensible occurrence.
I agree that all Boards of Educations should be accountable to parents, 
their
natural constituency.  I question, though, some of the reasoning used or
implied in this letter.
All New Brunswick BOE members do and must reside in New Brunswick, and it is
my understanding that most of those that have school-aged children have them
attending city schools.   What would assure the elected Board members have
their children attend city schools?
Performance at Lincoln School must be scrutinized, particularly because of
Rutgers' acclaimed involvement in the academic "enhancement" of this
particular school. But to compare New Brunswick schools to the State average
is inappropriate.
Although the district possesses a great deal of issues that need 
improvement,
the majority of the students attending New Brunswick Public Schools are
affected by many environmental factors that influence negatively on their
performance.  Poverty, overcrowded housing conditions, substance abuse,
delinquency, teen pregnancy, the inability of many parents to assist 
children
with coursework because of their lack of command of English or their work
schedules, among many other things, have a definite impact.  When compared 
to
other urban areas that share the same intensity of problems and barriers, 
New
Brunswick schools do surprisingly well.

Lastly, if 65 percent of the children enrolled in the public school district
is Latino, and most of their parents cannot yet vote - although contributing
to society and the tax base, whom will elected Board members represent?
Which constituency will be represented?  Could it be Senior Citizens on 
fixed
incomes - which have the highest percentage of participants in elections -
whom because of the unjust NJ tax structure are obliged to endeavor to 
reduce
their property taxes?  Moreover, I keep getting flashbacks of the abuses of
the elected Board in Newark and the patronage and corruption that occurred
there without concern for the welfare of students.

An elected Board might be a good idea.  But we need sound arguments to
support the question.

Guillo







unite the many, defeat the few!

Post ID:2559
Sender:GUILLO@...
Post Date/Time:2002-02-17 23:48:06
Subject:Re: [TheHubCityNJ] Make school board accountable to citizens
Message:

The cut in funding this year of ALL New Brunswick community preschool 
providers was enacted by the State Department of Education (it's still under 
appeal).  In order to equalize education between richer and poorer districts, 
the Supreme Court Abbott decision requires preschool - paid by the State - in 
the poorer districts.  That same Department, because of State legislation, 
requires local school districts to fund Charter Schools approved by the 
State.  Again, no local control of the issue, whatever type of Board exists.

The private High School is another matter.  Public dollars directed to a 
large absentee for-profit company is distasteful.  I'm waiting to see if it 
will be successful, and if it will hurt the main High School student 
population.  I'm also interested in the demographics of the school, and the 
demographics of the Charter School, for that matter.

I must totally agree that "there is no excuse whatever, given the vast wealth 
and education resources to be found in this city, why New Brunswick public 
school students should not be provided the highest level of education 
imaginable."  The available resources are not interacting effectively.

By the way, I didn't mean to prioritize any social problem over another.  
They all need attention.  Nonetheless, performance will be affected by 
environmental factors, even if students are provided the highest level of 
education imaginable.

My position on Latino parents is that now they DO have representation in the 
school Board.   With an elected Board …….. ?   Maybe.

Regardless, I still believe that an elected Board might be a good idea.  But 
we need sound arguments to support the question.  Maybe individuals that 
would run for an elected Board should begin disseminating platforms 
explaining how they could make the necessary changes?   If they have the 
answers, I'm sure the community would back them.

Guillo

Subject:Know your Rights Forum-March 9th
Message:

The The Malcom X Grassroots Movement and The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign 
invite organizations to endorse this activity and to mobilize their 
constituents and community.
_______________________________________________________________________
KNOW YOUR RIGHTS!!

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign and the Malcom X Grassroots Movement are 
calling on all activists, community organizers, and community members to

Post ID:2561
Sender:"Sash Zlatanovic" <aug_cae@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-02-18 12:01:09
Subject:Elected board of education vs. an appointed one
Message:

I apologize for interrupting your day, but I hope that this message should 
spark some interest.

I just wanted to comment on the issue of an elected board of education 
versus an appointed one in New Brunswick, NJ raised recently by Cliff Smith 
and an individual whom I've never met known simply as Guillo on the People's 
Campaign message group. Because of the length of this message, I took the 
liberty of providing for a table of contents.


I.   Arguments over an elected board of education in detail
II.  Arguments over an elected board of education, condensed
III. Advice on appeals to democracy
IV.  Letters to the editor
V.   Miscellaneous

Contact info: Sash Zlatanovic, 732-208-0000 & 732-342-9224


I'm also sending this message to many others, including members of the 
media, who might find this subject rather interesting. Below is a short 
one-paragraph description of this ongoing issue, after which the main body 
of my arguments will follow.

For years, the New Brunswick board of education has been appointed by Mayor 
James Cahill and many referenda have been placed on the ballot to answer 
this pressing question about what to do as New Brunswick schools are failing 
as health services and regular program instruction have been significantly 
cut for the schools, which could be said is being overlooked because many 
students are from poor Hispanic and black families. In 2000, this referendum 
was defeated by a margin of less than 1,000 votes. The mayor, elected by 
less than 12% of New Brunswick residents in 1998, has no real mandate and 
complacent voters have fallen victim to the Committee to Keep Politics Out 
of Our Schools, a political campaign that had raised slightly over $4,000 
from unreported contributors in addition to being investigated by the state 
Election Law Enforcement Commission in previous years.

Hopefully, members of the media will help raise awareness to this issue with 
these arguments and, in turn, many will find it helpful to read these 
articles.




I. ARGUMENTS OVER AN ELECTED BOE IN DETAIL




Much like having our government officials elected by the public, members of 
the New Brunswick board of education would be far better held accountable to 
the public--parents, students and residents alike--if they were to be 
elected rather than appointed. Members of the board of education would be 
residents of New Brunswick and would be held responsible for any failure to 
provide appropriate education directly by those who are most affected by it.

However much the mayor and his supporters would like to condemn the election 
of board members as introducing politics into the New Brunswick school 
system overlook one simple thing: their appointment is just as political. 
Patronage and nepotism abound to such an excess in such a system, though, 
that an elected board system is far more advantageous than otherwise. This 
would help explain why most other school districts--referring to the 
hundreds of districts in the state as well as the thousands outside 
it--prefer an elected system.

Does the mayor seriously think that he knows better than the hundreds of 
thousands who participate in elected board systems either as candidates or 
as voters? I suppose he does, the mayor's power over city education being 
rivaled only by his ego.

However, I should caution, though. From my own personal experience, two 
major drawbacks to having an elected board are that, first, the school 
budget is also open to defeat at the ballots since it, too, would be decided 
upon by the voters and, second, many vote for those who know little about 
good public policy.

Nevertheless, at first glance, these two seem to raise some concerns. 
However, even if it were the case that school budgets would be routinely and 
even at times soundly defeated, the state does provide an appeals process. 
Without going into too much detail, the budget would be appealed to the 
superintendent and eventually the state department of education. Eventually, 
the budget is nonetheless implemented, often at the discretion of appointed 
officials, but at least the public were allowed an opportunity to voice its 
opinion on the budget. Even indirectly, the public has an influence on how 
the budget is formulated through the election of board members, so it's the 
case that the public is altogether ignored on budget issues.

As for having people with no sense of good public policy being elected, I 
should point out that what is "good" public policy--one in which as many 
members of the public as possible benefit--should abstractly have various 
interests well balanced, leading to an acceptable policy that would be as 
broad and appealing as possible. Perhaps this definition may not be 
acceptable to some, but I wanted to avoid specifics to mention that board 
members would be sufficiently held accountable by the public and instances 
whereby cousins vote for one another when they know nothing about what to do 
for the common good would be rare and far apart, to say the least.

Nonetheless, I think it's safe to say that, when important school programs 
have been severely cut to such a degree that schools are no longer schools 
but run down human warehouses and day care centers and the BOE has failed to 
provide proper education, the New Brunswick BOE has failed the city and its 
children in no uncertain terms.

Be that as it may, whatever arguments that opponents to an elected board may 
raise fall short of persuasion if one were to realize that the vast majority 
of other school districts have boards that are elected, many of which 
oversee schools that are far better than New Brunswick's. I'm not trying to 
draw causation from this observation, but there's certainly a correlation. 
Moreover, those that remain appointed are largely school districts that have 
politicians whose interests are better served if they have direct and 
uninhibited control over education policy.




II. ARGUMENTS OVER AN ELECTED BOE, CONDENSED




In an elected board system, in short, board members are effectively far 
better held accountable than those appointed whose positions raise questions 
about patronage, a corrupting and counterproductive influence.

Guillo insisted on sound arguments and I hope I provided for these. In case 
if anyone wanted something short but comprehensive, here's a list of 
advantages of an elected board versus disadvantages and, if we were to weigh 
one against the other, a sensible person would agree that an elected system 
is far better.

SET A. Arguments in favor of an elected system
1. Members of the BOE held accountable to standards of success
2. Patronage and nepotism are far less likely
3. Interests are better represented
4. Members of the BOE more likely to be open to the public

SET B1. Arguments against an elected system
1. School budgets may be defeated
2. Politicizes education
3. Mayor has less control over education policy
4. Popular control takes away from professional control (if one were to 
believe that patronage of unqualified individuals leads to professionalism)

SET B2. Counter-arguments against opposition to an elected system
1. There's an appeals process for defeated budgets, so funding wouldn't 
actually be detrimentally affected
2. Education is politicized anyway when a government official appoints and 
anything that can garner opinion and criticism is political by nature, so 
"politics" is inevitably unavoidable
3. Concentration of influence over public policy (e.g., in the form of a 
mayorally appointed BOE) has never been compatible with American political 
thought anyway for obvious reasons
4. Tens of thousands of school districts have elected BOE's and 
professionals would still have an incredible influence over education policy 
by advising the public and board members

N.b. Each point to sets B1 and B2 correspond with one another. For example, 
point #1 in set B2 (in favor of an elected BOE) is a response to point #1 in 
set B1 (opposed to an elected BOE).




III. ADVICE ON APPEALS TO DEMOCRACY.




Concerning appeals to democracy, I don't often make such arguments because 
it sounds demagogic. These arguments are actually unappealing to many, many 
voters. However, I would suggest, instead, using the above arguments to make 
the same conclusion that appeals to democracy would make: more 
accountability encourages better public policy. By not making such appeals 
to democracy--which more or less appeals to one's emotion toward democracy 
rather than intellect--we avoid having accusations of demagoguery and 
charges of introducing politics into schools--which certainly does appeal to 
many other voters who might otherwise support us had we chosen better 
words--made against us.

In fact, many, many people would prefer wise public policy over popular 
control. However, to avoid this dilemma, we should link the two together: 
through accountability, better education policy would take hold. (See parts 
I and II.) Nevertheless, appeals to democracy are blindly populist and it 
succeeds in turning off voters and I suggest using more substantive 
arguments rather than, at least in my opinion, emotional appeals.




IV. LETTERS TO THE EDITOR




Tomorrow evening the BOE will meet at the high school on Livingston. I would 
suggest, if anyone's interested, people should post messages on this message 
board or email me that would be in support of an elected board or if there 
are any criticisms that I may have overlooked. In addition, I'd like people 
to volunteer to present each of the bulleted arguments from the above list 
of arguments in both letters to the editor and at city council and BOE 
meetings. The next BOE meeting is at 7:30pm at the New Brunswick High School 
along Livingston Ave on February 19th and the next city council meeting is 
at 7pm at the New Brunswick City Hall at 78 Bayard on February 20th.




V. MISC.




Anyone who prefers to read a much shorter message that goes straight to the 
point, please refer to the Home News Tribune letter to the editor from 
February 8th. I strongly recommend others to use material presented in this 
email to support an elected board of education for no better reasons than 
wanting better education policy (in turn, safer streets and better standards 
of living) and greater accessibility and openness for the public in the form 
of a letter to the editor. If you wish more information can certainly be 
provided from many weeks of research; just email me.

For those in favor of an elected BOE, I would suggest taking into account my 
advice, because I believe that in doing so we increase our chances of 
success and progress toward better education. For those opposed, I would 
suggest refining your arguments and present them to me and I will, most 
certainly, thoroughly destroy them.

I hope to hear from you soon and I sincerely thank you for having read this 
rather long message.




CONTACT INFO
Sash Zlatanovic
732-208-0000
732-342-9224

Post ID:2562
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-02-20 13:40:50
Subject:For the Independent Peaceful Reunification of Korea
Message:

Kim Il Sung

From the Speech at the 15th Anniversary Celebration of the August 15 
Liberation, the National Holiday of the Korean People [Excerpt]

August 14, 1960


So long as an aggressive army of foreign imperialism exists in his 
territory, no one can speak of his national independence not can the people 
live in peace.  At present, the root cause of our country�s division and off 
all misery and sufferings of the south Korean people lies in the occupation 
of south Korea by the aggressive army of the U.S. imperialists and their 
aggressive policy.  As long as south Korea is in the grip of that army, the 
peaceful reunification of our country will never be realized, nor will the 
south Korean people be free from the present miserable plight.

The U.S. imperialist aggressor army which is occupying south Korea is the 
ringleader of the reactionary forces there.  It is a band of robbers 
plundering the south Korean people of their properties and perpetrating all 
sorts of atrocities.  This imperialist aggressor army of the United States, 
the ringleader of reaction and gangsterism, is th e primary target in the 
struggle of the south Korean people.

Therefore, the workers, peasants and all other sections of the population of 
south Korea must, first of all, resolutely oppose the U.S. imperialist 
aggressive forces and fight to force their army out of south Korea.  When 
all the patriotic people in south Korea rise as one in the anti-U.S. 
struggle, these aggressors will be unable to stay there but will be 
compelled to withdraw�

Today the U.S. imperialists, dismayed at the awakening of the south Korean 
people and their unceasing struggle, are resorting to every trick to 
maintain their colonial rule over south Korea.  They are bringing new-type 
weapons into south Korea, reinforcing their troops there and intensifying 
war preparations, while frantically trying to put the paralyzed puppet 
ruling apparatus in order.  The south Korean reactionary clique is trying to 
dampen the fighting spirit of the people by means of repression and 
deception, faithfully carrying out the orders of their American masters�

Today the south Korean people are in an indescribably wretched plight.  The 
wages of the workers are less than one-third of the minimum living costs, 
and even their payment is usually overdue a few months, sometimes more than 
half a year.  Peasants are cruelly exploited by landlords and usurers.  Most 
of them are under heavy debts, and over one million peasant households run 
out of food every year.  Millions of unemployed and semi-employed are on the 
verge of starvation, and hundreds of children are wandering around and 
begging in the streets�

Comrades, the only way to save the present situation in south Korea and 
finally solve the Korean question lies in driving out the U.S. army and 
reunifying the country peacefully.

The peaceful reunification of our country must be achieved independently by 
holding free general elections throughout north and south Korea on a 
democratic basis without any foreign interference.  This is our consistent 
stand on the question of national reunification�

The south Korean rulers say that they cannot accept a free north-south 
general election because it means �collaboration with the Communists� and 
involves the danger of being �communized.�

However, those who really want to fight for the people and defend the 
interests of the nation will never be afraid of the Communists or oppose 
�collaboration with the Communists,� because the Communists always work for 
the people; they are the most ardent defender of the national interests and 
the staunchest patriots.  This was why the Japanese imperialists feared the 
Korean Communists more than anybody else and repressed them most ruthlessly�

We Communists always maintain that we will closely unite and cooperate with 
all political parties, social organizations and individual personages that 
fight for peaceful reunification and national independence.  We will 
cooperate with all persons, regardless of their past, if they come out for 
the peaceful reunification of the country�

There is no denying the fact that the most reasonable and realistic way to 
peaceful national reunification is to hold free north-south general 
elections on a democratic basis without any foreign interference.  We appeal 
to all the political parties and social organizations and the people of all 
walks of life in south Korea to come out for holding such elections.

If the south Korean authorities still cannot agree to free north-south 
general elections for fear of the whole of south Korea being communized, 
then we must work out, to start with, even transitional measures for 
settling the burning problems of the nation.

As one of such measures, we propose that a Confederation of north and south 
Korea be instituted.  We propose to establish the Confederation by way of 
setting up a supreme national committee composed of the representatives of 
the Government of the Democratic People�s Republic of Korea and the 
Government of the �Republic of Korea� mainly to regulate the economic and 
cultural development of north and south Korea in a uniform manner, while 
retaining, for the time being, the present political systems in north and 
south Korea and maintaining the independent activities of the two 
governments.

The establishment of such a Confederation will enable the north and the 
south to understand and cooperate with each other by ensuring contacts and 
negotiations between them and removing mutual distrust.  We consider that, 
if the free north-south elections are held under such circumstances, the 
complete peaceful reunification of our country can be realized.

In particular, the establishment of such a Confederation will make it 
possible to save south Korea from economic ruin by having the supreme 
national committee consider economic and cultural matters beneficial to the 
whole nation and ensure economic and cultural exchanges and mutual 
cooperation between north and south Korea, even though the Confederation 
does not  mean the formation of a united coalition government representing 
all social strata and therefore cannot exercise united state leadership�

If the south Korean authorities consider that even the Confederation we 
propose is still unacceptable to them, we once again propose that a purely 
economic commission composed of representatives of the business circles of 
north and south Korea be set up to exchange goods between the north and the 
south and to cooperate with and help each other in economic construction.  
Thus, we must, first of all, relieve the brothers and sisters in south Korea 
from hunger and poverty, setting aside the political question.

Along with the economic exchange between the north and the south, cultural 
exchange should be conducted on an extensive scale and the people allowed to 
travel freely.

The Korean nation is a homogenous nation with the same language, spoken and 
written, and has inherited the same historical and cultural traditions.  
However, we have been separated from each other for fifteen years, unable to 
visit each other, meet each other and even write to each other.  
Consequently, even our language is gradually changing in a different way in 
the two zones, and so are our culture and customs.  Worse still, decadent 
Yankee culture and the American way of life hold sway and our national 
culture and the beautiful customs of our people are being trampled upon in 
south Korea.

This hinders the uniform development of our nation and, in particular, 
threatens the danger of plunging south Korea into an inescapable quagmire of 
corruption and degeneration.

We should under no circumstances allow ourselves to ruin the future destiny 
of the nation on account of political antagonism and thus commit crimes 
indelible for generations to come.

We once again propose that the mutual visit of cultural missions and mutual 
exchanges in science, culture, arts, sports and in all other fields be 
effected between the north and the south.  At least, correspondence should 
be made possible between parents and children, brothers and sisters, 
relatives and friends, and the people allowed to travel freely across the 
country�

In order to solve these questions, representatives of north and south Korea 
should, first of all, get together and negotiate.  Unscrupulously saying 
this is wrong, this is impossible, or something in a similar vein, even 
before meeting and talking with each other, is not a proper attitude 
favoring the solution of questions.  Such an attitude benefits only the U.S. 
imperialists who are trying to keep our nation split and pit our people 
against each other and turn south Korea into their permanent colony.  If we 
keep ourselves divided and our doors shut to each other, the situation will 
be further aggravated and south Korean people will suffer greater misery and 
hardships.

We propose to the south Korean authorities, political parties, social 
organizations and individual personages that representatives of north and 
south Korea meet at the earliest date in Pyong-yang, Seoul, or at Panmunjom 
to negotiate about all the above issues.

There is no reason why the Koreans, one and the same nation, should not meet 
together and negotiate.  Why should we, people in the north, continue to 
hold talks with the Yankees about the question of our own country at 
Panmunjom, a place in our own land?  Why should the south Korean people be 
deprived of their seats by the Yankees?  The Yankees must pull out and 
Koreans should sit together and discuss the Korean question.

All political parties, social organizations and individual personages in 
south Korea should demand that the north and the south hold negotiations as 
soon as possible.  All patriotic people in south Korea must struggle for 
economic and cultural exchange between the north and the south, for the 
reduction of the vast army of south Korea and for free north-south general 
elections.

The peaceful reunification of our country can by no means be easily 
achieved.  We must not forget even for a moment that the U.S. imperialists, 
the ringleaders of world reaction, are occupying south Korea.  The peaceful 
reunification of the country can be achieved only by a persistent struggle 
of all the Korean people.

When the socialist forces are further strengthened in the northern half of 
the Republic and all the patriotic forces in south Korea firmly unite and 
turn out in the decisive struggle against the U.S. imperialists and their 
lackeys, we will be able to drive the U.S. imperialist aggressors out of 
south Korea and accomplish the great historic task of the peaceful 
reunification of our country.







unite the many, defeat the few!

Pedro Colon Almenas was sentenced today in a court room packed with hundreds 
of youth/students/supporters in Puerto Rico.  According to an over the phone 
report we received this early evening, the youth/students of Puerto Rico 
organized a massive total island student strike that had amazing 
ramifications throughout the island yesterday, there were various solidarity 
activities/vigils and press events this week that created an  amazing 
pressure on Judge Hector Lafitte (a pro-Navy ex-JAG lawyer infamous for his 
serving out outrageous sentences to civil disobedients).  This pressure 
forced Lafitte to sentence pedro to a year and three years of probation in 
stead of the possible 3-5 years that the prosecution was pushing.

Committee in Solidairty with Pedro's press statement.

with the independent will of Koreans to build their own form of socialism,

orchestrated by Kim Yong Il.  Since then, North Korea has been nothing short

North restraining the expansionistic appetites that typically accompany
fascism.

Identifying North Korea as an ally of progressive movements merely because
it is on the U.S. government's 'shit list' is a mistake.  We would do best
to denounce equally the arrogance and ignorance of GWB's sabre-rattling as
well as the dismal path of North Korean 'socialism.'

Chris

walks of life in south Korea to come out for holding such elections.

If the south Korean authorities still cannot agree to free north-south
general elections for fear of the whole of south Korea being communized,
then we must work out, to start with, even transitional measures for
settling the burning problems of the nation.

As one of such measures, we propose that a Confederation of north and south
Korea be instituted.  We propose to establish the Confederation by way of
setting up a supreme national committee composed of the representatives of
the Government of the Democratic People�s Republic of Korea and the
Government of the �Republic of Korea� mainly to regulate the economic and
cultural development of north and south Korea in a uniform manner, while
retaining, for the time being, the present political systems in north and
south Korea and maintaining the independent activities of the two
governments.

The establishment of such a Confederation will enable the north and the
south to understand and cooperate with each other by ensuring contacts and
negotiations between them and removing mutual distrust.  We consider that,
if the free north-south elections are held under such circumstances, the
complete peaceful reunification of our country can be realized.

In particular, the establishment of such a Confederation will make it
possible to save south Korea from economic ruin by having the supreme
national committee consider economic and cultural matters beneficial to the
whole nation and ensure economic and cultural exchanges and mutual
cooperation between north and south Korea, even though the Confederation
does not  mean the formation of a united coalition government representing
all social strata and therefore cannot exercise united state leadership�

If the south Korean authorities consider that even the Confederation we
propose is still unacceptable to them, we once again propose that a purely
economic commission composed of representatives of the business circles of
north and south Korea be set up to exchange goods between the north and the
south and to cooperate with and help each other in economic construction.
Thus, we must, first of all, relieve the brothers and sisters in south Korea
from hunger and poverty, setting aside the political question.

Along with the economic exchange between the north and the south, cultural
exchange should be conducted on an extensive scale and the people allowed to
travel freely.

The Korean nation is a homogenous nation with the same language, spoken and
written, and has inherited the same historical and cultural traditions.
However, we have been separated from each other for fifteen years, unable to
visit each other, meet each other and even write to each other.
Consequently, even our language is gradually changing in a different way in
the two zones, and so are our culture and customs.  Worse still, decadent
Yankee culture and the American way of life hold sway and our national
culture and the beautiful customs of our people are being trampled upon in
south Korea.

This hinders the uniform development of our nation and, in particular,
threatens the danger of plunging south Korea into an inescapable quagmire of
corruption and degeneration.

We should under no circumstances allow ourselves to ruin the future destiny
of the nation on account of political antagonism and thus commit crimes
indelible for generations to come.

We once again propose that the mutual visit of cultural missions and mutual
exchanges in science, culture, arts, sports and in all other fields be
effected between the north and the south.  At least, correspondence should
be made possible between parents and children, brothers and sisters,
relatives and friends, and the people allowed to travel freely across the
country�

In order to solve these questions, representatives of north and south Korea
should, first of all, get together and negotiate.  Unscrupulously saying
this is wrong, this is impossible, or something in a similar vein, even
before meeting and talking with each other, is not a proper attitude
favoring the solution of questions.  Such an attitude benefits only the U.S.
imperialists who are trying to keep our nation split and pit our people
against each other and turn south Korea into their permanent colony.  If we
keep ourselves divided and our doors shut to each other, the situation will
be further aggravated and south Korean people will suffer greater misery and
hardships.

We propose to the south Korean authorities, political parties, social
organizations and individual personages that representatives of north and
south Korea meet at the earliest date in Pyong-yang, Seoul, or at Panmunjom
to negotiate about all the above issues.

There is no reason why the Koreans, one and the same nation, should not meet
together and negotiate.  Why should we, people in the north, continue to
hold talks with the Yankees about the question of our own country at
Panmunjom, a place in our own land?  Why should the south Korean people be
deprived of their seats by the Yankees?  The Yankees must pull out and
Koreans should sit together and discuss the Korean question.

All political parties, social organizations and individual personages in
south Korea should demand that the north and the south hold negotiations as
soon as possible.  All patriotic people in south Korea must struggle for
economic and cultural exchange between the north and the south, for the
reduction of the vast army of south Korea and for free north-south general
elections.

The peaceful reunification of our country can by no means be easily
achieved.  We must not forget even for a moment that the U.S. imperialists,
the ringleaders of world reaction, are occupying south Korea.  The peaceful
reunification of the country can be achieved only by a persistent struggle
of all the Korean people.

When the socialist forces are further strengthened in the northern half of
the Republic and all the patriotic forces in south Korea firmly unite and
turn out in the decisive struggle against the U.S. imperialists and their
lackeys, we will be able to drive the U.S. imperialist aggressors out of
south Korea and accomplish the great historic task of the peaceful
reunification of our country.







unite the many, defeat the few!

Post ID:2578
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-03-05 14:28:25
Subject:nb activists' trial
Message:


New Brunswick
Peoples� Campaign 2002
unite the many, defeat the few!

Contact Cliff Smith 732.214.8828

9 March, 02

for immediate release




The trial of community activists, Cliff and Joe Smith, arrested at the 15 
January New Brunswick Board of Education meeting, is scheduled for 20 March, 
5:30pm, in the NB Municipal Courthouse.

The activists, who have long organized for an elected school board, were 
charged with disrupting a public meeting, after Cliff Smith distributed 
copies of recent, low standardized test scores.  Joe Smith was also charged 
with two counts of simple assault.

The activists have filed their own charges of assault against High School 
Principal Pierre Embry, and Donald Bowling, who physically threw them from 
the meeting.  �The administration prefers thug tactics to cover up their 
criminal failure of New Brunswick�s youth,� said Joe Smith.  �No amount of 
arrests and intimidation will help raise these test scores.�

11th grade students scored 51% passing in the High School Proficiency Test, 
required for graduation.  This is down from 74.5% in 1999.  Lincoln School 
4th graders scored 12.5% passing their own test.  The district�s scores are 
the lowest in Middlesex County.

New Brunswick has the only un-elected Board of Education in Middlesex 
County.  The Board is instead appointed by Mayor Cahill, who is up for 
election in November.  The activists state that they are being strong-armed 
as an opening salvo in Cahill�s campaign.

Subject:UPDATE ON THE CUBAN FIVE
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom campaign  urges folks to read this VERY IMPORTANT 
UPDATE ON THE FIVE CUBAN POLITICAL PRISONERS!!  Please write to them and 
send them commissary donations as well.
___________________________________________________________________

Dear friends of the five Cuban heroes:

It has been awhile since we sent out an update.
We wanted to wait until Gerardo, Antonio, Ramon,
Rene and Fernando were transferred.

The process has taken up to several weeks for them
to finally be moved.

All five brothers have been sent to separate prisons
across the country, another example of the U.S.
government's callousness, knowing that the five are
very close and it meant a great deal to them to be
together during their imprisonment in Miami.

In Miami they were able to consult collectively with
their attorneys and to see each other periodically.

The following are the new addresses of the companeros:
(Please note that Gerardo Hernandez, who used to have
the name Manuel Viramontes in Miami, is now under his
real name Gerardo Hernandez.

Rene Gonzalez
Reg. #58738-004
FCI Loretto
P.O. Box 1000
Loretto, PA 15940

Gerardo Hernandez
#58739-004
U.S. Penitentiary-Lompoc
3901 Klein Blvd.
Lompoc, CA 93436

(For RAMON LABANINO)
Write to: Luis Medina
#58734-004
U.S.P. Beaumont
P.O. Box 26035
Beaumont TX 77720-6035

(For FERNANDO GONZALEZ)
Write to: Ruben Campa
#58733-004
F.C.I. Oxford
P.O. Box 1000
Oxford WI  53952-0505

Antonio Guerrero
#58741-004
U.S.P. Florence
P.O. Box 7500
Florence CO 81226

Please be sure and write to them as soon as you
can. In the meantime, appeals have not been filed,
as court dates have not been set yet. Several of
the attorneys will continue as their appeals counsel.
In discussions with their attorneys, they have told
us that three basic points of appeals will be followed,
for now.

They are:
1. On the court's failure to order a change of venue:
In such a politically-charged and hostile environment
as Miami, the anti-Cuba terrorist capital, it was not
possible for the court to meet one of the most basic
criteria for a "fair" trial, that of an impartial and
unbiased jury, free of pressure from right-wing forces.

2. On Gerardo's murder conspiracy conviction, the
jury agreed with the U.S. prosecutor's outrageous
claim that Gerardo had conspired with Cuba to have
the pilots (who invaded Cuban airspace Feb. 24,
1996) shot down in international waters.
That was the U.S.contention, that they were
deliberately shot down in international waters, thus
the U.S. argued against Cuba's rightful claim that it
was defending its territorial space when the "Brothers
to the Rescue" planes invaded. The jury ignored
defense witnesses from the U.S. military, who actually
showed that the planes had indeed been in Cuban
airspace.

3. On the espionage conspiracy, in which three of
the brothers were convicted. The defense will argue
in appeals that the U.S. government never proved in
the 14,000 pages of transcript and 7 months of trial,
that the companeros had engaged in espionage on the
United States. In the meantime, there is a national tour
in several U.S. cities to publicize and further build
support for the five.

Following are some
of the tour dates:
SEATTLE:
Saturday, March 9, Reception for Maggie Becker,
companera of Antonio Guerrero, and Gloria La Riva,
7:00 p.m., public meeting on the Five.
For information call Tom Warner (206) 523-1720

CHICAGO:
Friday, March 15 at 7 p.m. at the DePaul University
Student Union, 2250 N.Sheffield, at Belden.
Speakers: Florentino Batista, Diplomat, Cuban Interests
Section, and Gloria La Riva,
Coordinator, National Committee to Free the Five
U.S.-Held Cuban Political Prisoners

MILWAUKEE:
Saturday, March 16, 2pm. Central United Methodist
Church, 639 N. 25th St.

DETROIT:
Sunday, March 17, 1:30-5 p.m., Swords into
Plowshares Gallery, Adams St., East of Woodward
at Grand Circus Park. Video with interviews offamily
members and discussion on how this case relates to
the current "war on terrorism"?  What is the history of
terrorist attacks against Cuba? In Detroit, call: Justice
for Cuba Coalition 313 561 8330 or 313 516 7898
E-mail: laborexchange@... .

One major focus of our work is the collection of
petitions to show wide support across the U.S. for
the five companeros. We are urging supporters to
get a copy of the petition (available on the webpage:
www.actionsf.org ) calling for George W. Bush to
free the Five. Please distribute it at political and
other public events. For example in San Francisco
and New York, activists have made it a habit to take
the petition  to many events, make an announcement
if possible, and collect signatures. We have been able
to get up to hundreds at major events. For more
information, and literature, and the new video, callus at
415-821-6545, or e-mail us at: freethefive@...

Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-03-11 12:11:59
Subject:play: 'the cradle will rock'
Message:

Welcome to Chalkdust Productions website! We are a new theatrical production 
company in the Central Jersey Area.

                                                                             
               Press Release February 15, 2002
  FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

  For further information, please contact Adam Fitting
  afitting@... 609-509-0548

  CHALKDUST PRODUCTIONS PRESENTS "THE CRADLE WILL ROCK"

  Chalkdust Productions, Central Jersey�s newest non-profit theatre group, 
will present its inaugural production, Marc Blitzstein's The Cradle Will 
Rock at the Princeton Arts Council at the corner of Witherspoon Street and 
Paul Robeson Place on March 8, 9, 14, 15, 16, 21, and 22 at 8:00pm. 
Admission is $10 for Students and Senior Citizens, $12 General Admission. 
For reservations/information visit www.chalkdustproductions.org or call 
609-430-9345.

  The Cradle Will Rock was written in 1937 originally intended to be 
presented by the WPA Theatre of the Federal Works Administration with John 
Houseman as producer and Orson Welles directing. The political opposition to 
certain ofthe administration's projects, particularly those judged to 
contain un-American themes and sentiments, the history of the show's 
premiere became almost as legendary as the performance itself; a story 
related in Tim Robbin's recent mostly factual 1999 film.

  The work is a "play with music" which allegorically relates a la Bertolt 
Brecht the advent of the labor union movement in the United States. To form 
a band of resistance against the organization of the unions in the fictional 
Steeltown USA, Mr. Mister, the wealthiest man in the community, buys the 
influence of the major town leaders to join his Liberty Committee. When the 
members of this committee are mistakenly hauled into the local nightcourt 
while observing a union rally, the story of each committee member�s �fall� 
is told in flashback. Also introduced are the local druggist whose life has 
been caught up in the activities and a young woman forced into prostitution 
by poverty.

  Blitzstein�s treatment of the politics of war, art, labor, ethics and 
human values are especially timely. This classic work of American theatre 
challenges our assumptions about our culture and shakes the roots of our 
collective subconscious.

  Cast members include Alexandra Tobia and Adam Fitting, of Princeton;
  Timothy Jones and Teresa Hui, of Westminster Choir College; Jennifer Day, 
Amy Crosby, Brianne Shurolt of Cranbury; Michelle Wynn of Somerset; Jay 
Casale of Manalapan; Anne Howe of Mantua; Keith Sampino of Old Bridge; Jay 
Brancato of Parsippany; Loreto Torres of Somerset; and Brian Bara of 
Levittown, PA. The work is directed by Theodore R. Clement of Princeton, NJ, 
with musical direction by Kenneth P. Howard of Mercerville, NJ. Stage 
management by Barbara Gianotto of East Brunswick.

Post ID:2591
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-03-11 14:38:19
Subject:Marshall Trial
Message:

To: New Brunswick Peoples' Campaign and Sisterhood & Struggle:

From: Drena T. Carter (Mother of Corey Ashford, key witness, State v.
                       James Marshall)

8 March, 2002

I deeply regret not being able to attend your meeting today, however, due to 
the serious nature of this case, I was advised against attending.  I do 
however, would like to thank each and every one of you for your support and 
continued interest surrounding the police corruption case of Jim Marshall.

Unfortunately because I am a witness in this case, particulars cannot be 
discussed.  However, I will fill you in on facts that have been made public 
either in court, or the newspapers.  People seem to think that James 
Marshall was acquitted and are deeply confused with regards to legalities of 
this case.  It is most unfortunate that people only read the headlines and 
not between the lines especially in cases such as this one.  James Marshall 
was losing this trial by a landslide, and the only way that his attorney 
could come up for air was to drag things out to the point where the jury was 
getting restless and bored.  After six weeks of trial, only four witnesses 
had been called, one being the key witness, my son, Corey Ashford.  After 
the prosecution concluded its questioning of Corey, the defense attorney 
begun its cross examination.  However, the questions were redundant of what 
the prosecution had just finished up with.  Most would have questioned the 
line of mild questioning that the defense attorney brought to the table.  
However, we all know now that the defense attorney had a hidden agenda, and 
suddenly he was sick for a week and court was postponed only to find out 
that some of the jurors asked to be released due to prior commitments.  
Either this was a stroke of luck for the Marshall team, or a well planned 
strategy on the part of Marshall's attorney.  They say that most attorneys 
can feel the jury, and I don't think there were any connections on behalf of 
Marshall.  Marshall's attorney is rude and obnoxious, and tries to set the 
scene of the courtroom of a Perry Mason show.  However, after the tapes were 
played, the jury seemed quite interested.

After testifying, I appeared on the day my son was to testify.  Noone in the 
courtroom had a problem with my presence, with the exception of Marshall's 
attorney.  He made up the excuse that he might have to call me back as a 
witness.  However, Corey's girlfriend was also asked to leave the courtroom 
[illegible] witness to testify.  Marshall's attorney's real motive was to 
make it seem like Corey had no family support, and that he was just some 
street thug out there alone making this entire thing up, while Marshall is 
being surrounded by a loving family that has his support.

Marshall is as guilty as the day is long, however, he is determined that he 
won't go down without a fight not caring who he hurts or destroys.  His 
pride won't allow him to take a plea bargain although his attorney did 
inquire about having one on the table...  And where is he getting all this 
money for legal fees.  According to a very reliable source, Marshall's 
attorney fees have exceeded $100,000, and he still has three more trials to 
go.  I didn't realize legal cops made that kind of money, or are the 
taxpayers of New Brunswick footing the bill?

I say to you people, if Marshall walks, the struggle for justice will have 
to start from the beginning again.  Everything that you have worked for in 
demanding fair and equal treatment for mankind will be conceived as a joke.  
Don't let this happen.  If Marshall walks, so should every criminal that has 
ever been locked up for selling and distribution of illegal drugs, not to 
mention the king pin of a brothel aka whorehouse.

James Marshall has tried to destroy my family, however, we are strong and 
believe in the fight.  If we all weren't witnesses, we'd be passing out 
fliers and sitting in the courtroom just as you are.  However, we don't want 
any more excuses for mistrials and delays, so we must stay in the 
background.  We want Marshall to pay for his crime and do his time.  If 
there is justice in Middlesex County, this will happen.  However, the only 
way that justice will be served is if the good people of New Brunswick and 
the surrounding areas come forward and demand just that, justice be served.  
Stop pussyfooting with Marshall and get this nightmare over with.  How can a 
convicted felon be allowed to walk freely as we law abiding citizens do, 
leave town at his leisure and continue to manipulate the system.  Who does 
Marshall really have in his back pocket, or should I say his little black 
book.

Again, I express my deepest regrets for not physically being here, however, 
you have my full support in all that you do.  Peace and strength be with 
you.

Sincerely,

Drena T. Carter
