Tuesday, April 9, 2002

Dear Friends and Supporters of Nicaragua:

With sadness and a great sense of moral outrage we report that Francisco 
Jos� Garc�a Valle, esteemed professor at the University of the Autonomous 
Regions  of the Caribbean Coast of Nicaragua and husband of Dr. Mar�a Luisa 
Acosta, internationally renown indigenous human rights lawyer was 
assassinated in his home on Monday night.

At the time of his murder, his wife was meeting with the IFCO/Pastors for 
Peace Central American Caravan to Chiapas, Honduras and Nicaragua, which had 
been in the region for the last week and a half.  Maria, who has received 
threats to her physical safety in the past because of her work advocating on 
behalf of indigenous communities fighting for their land and other basic 
human rights, was briefing the caravan on an important case that she is 
currently working on.  Had she not been away from her home meeting with the 
caravan, she could have met with the same fate as her husband.

Francisco Jose was found bound and gagged, shot in his heart.  A police 
investigation is under way, however at this time, there is no information 
available about who is responsible for this heinous act.

The caravan members were able to accompany Attorney Acosta today, but we 
remain extremely concerned about her continued safety given this violent 
attack against her immediate family.  The caravan held a press conference 
Tuesday afternoon in Managua to call for the immediate apprehension of the 
assassins and for the guaranteed protection of Attorney Acosta and her 
family.

IFCO/Pastors for Peace is urgently requesting that you communicate your 
concern to Nicaraguan President Enrique Bola�os, specifically calling to:

1.  Express your  outrage at the senseless murder of Francisco Jos� Garc�a 
Valle and concern for the security of Maria Acosta and her family, who have 
been at the forefront of the struggle for indigenous rights in the region.
2.  Demand that the security of Maria Acosta and her family be ensured by 
the government of Nicaragua and that a rigorous, stepped up investigation 
into the murder begin NOW.
3.  Demand that the assassins be immediately apprehended and brought to 
justice.

Please address your letters to President Enrique Bola�os to:
The Nicaraguan Ambassador
The Republic of Nicaragua
1627 New Hampshire Avenue, NW
Washington DC 20009
Telephone: (202) 9396570
Fax: (202) 939-6574
More information as to where to send messages of condolence and solidarity, 
as well as future actions to take, will be available shortly.
IFCO/Pastors for Peace
402 W 145th Street, New York City, NY 10031
212-926-5757; fax: 212-926-5842; email: ifco@...;
web: http://www.ifconews.org

with Palestinians at Brower Commons, College Avenue Campus, Rutgers
University.

While the occupied territories are under renewed assault, it is up to us to
take a stand, across the country and around the world, and tell our
government and the Israeli government that this is *not acceptable*, and
that there is a strong force of solidarity present for Palestinians.

Even if you can come for 5 minutes, come. It can make a difference!

Subject:Women Unite! Take Back the Night!
Message:

The annual Take Back the Night rally and march against gender violence,
domestic abuse, sexual assault and gender oppression will take place
Thursday, April 11.

The women's rally will begin at 7:00 PM at Voorhees Chapel on Douglass
College campus, and include a number of student and community speakers,
performers, poets and musicians, as well as keynote speaker Kate Bornstein,
transgender activist.

From Voorhees, women will march down George Street to the College Avenue
Campus at approximately 9:30 PM, symbolically taking back the night in New
Brunswick and at Rutgers.

The women's march will join men at Brower Commons at 10:00 PM for a co-ed
speakout and rally with open mic, where all are welcome to share their
stories and experiences, speak and march.

The Middlesex County Rape Crisis Center will display an exhibit on domestic
violence, as well as providing counselors for the Brower Commons open mic.
All are welcome and encouraged to attend!

Post ID:2664
Sender:Richard Rabinowitz <rickyrab@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-11 22:53:41
Subject:Don't just take back the night... keep it! here's how
Message:


---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 11 Apr 2002 01:09:02 
From: Jaclyn
To: the folks at RU
Subject: Advice on violence-free dating

      When it comes to dating, there seem to be many contradictions in
"the rules."  In my opinion, most circumstances require different actions
and reactions, and therefore can't be part of a clear dating game.  You
need to understand the person, the situation, and then decide how to act
based on your best judgement.   There is one charastic of most women that
may help you.  In fact, you will realize that men and women are the same
in this way.  For example, be yourself and don't pretend to be anyone
else, but DO NOT act too forward and eager by being overly-nice and
smothering.  You would not want a girl who called you all the time and
followed you around.  Both men and women (as much as it seems stupid)
will be more interested in someone who is harder to get.  Another
suggestion regarding looking for a girlfriend is not to go for a girl
solely because you find her attractive.  Make sure she is smart and you
like her personality.  The best relationships are often found through
friendships.  However, be careful, friendships can also be ruined in this
way.  There are ways to tell if someone is interested in you.  Trust your
instincts.  Think about the way a girl looks at you and the body
language.  Regarding asking a girl out: go for it -as long as you have
talked to her for a little while.  Keep in mind though, most guys get
"shot down" 99% of the time.  DO NOT loose confidence if that happens a
lot.  That happens A LOT to every guy!  The best advise I can give you is
to always be yourself, but do not open your soul until the girl deserves
to be so close to you.  You will find someone who is right for you, but
relationships are never easy.  Even when you love someone there are
fights.  Furthermore, you know how much your parents can piss you off? 
A woman you love can and will piss you off even more!  This happens when
you care so much about a person.  Believe me, no one can make me more mad
than Ian.  Be prepared to hold your temper.  Staying in love is constant
work.  Make sure you are confident and sure of yourself before entering a
relationship.  People make a mistake when they try to understand who they
are and gain confidence through someone else.  Adding another person
makes some things in life easier and other things much harder.  Look for
someone to have fun with and then see what happens!  A great woman will
brighten your life-most of the time- and you will be a wonderful gift to
her life. 

            Sorry about the spelling.  I hope I said a few interesting
things.


                                 Wish you good luck,
						
						 Jaclyn

Subject:Black Panther Reunion/Conference
Message:

The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign cannot stress enough the monumental 
importance of this conference/reunion.  Please read and foward this 
information out.  Please make plans to attend, an activity such as this 
cannot be missed!!

FREE ALL POLITICAL PRISOENRS!!
The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
ProLibertad@...
http://www.ProLibertad.org
Bronx 718-601-4751
Manhattan 212-927-9065
New Jersey 201-435-3244

It'sAbout Time
Committee to Celebrate the Founding of the
Black Panther Party
PO Box 221100
Sacramento CA 95822
(916) 455-0908

Jonina Abron
Safiya Bukhari
Clark (Santa Rita) Bailey
Kathleen Cleaver
Nzinga Conway
Emory Douglas
Claudia Grayson (Sister Sheba)
William (Billy X) Jennings
Akua Njeri (Deborah Johnson)
Talibah Shakir Gail Shaw

April 2, 2002
PRESS RELEASE

October 2001 marked the 35th Anniversary of the founding of
the Black Panther Party for Self Defense (BPP). As a result
of the events of September 11th, the BPP Reunion and
Conference originally planned to take place in October was
postponed and has been rescheduled for April 18th through 20th,
2002. Although the origins of the BPP were in Oakland, CA,
and previous conferences have been held in California, the
Black Panther Party had over 48 offices around the country
and many of our major offices were on the east coast. This
year's celebration will be held in Washington DC to recognize
the contributions of our east coast comrades. This event will
take place at the University of the District of Columbia, in
Washington DC. Previous registrations and advertising will
be honored.

The Conference will feature panel discussions on reparations
for the descendants of African slaves, political prisoners and
Cointelpro (the FBI's illegal program to disrupt progressive
political groups and destroy the BPP). The conference will
feature workshops designed to formulate strategies to obtain
freedom for political prisoners, combat police brutality,
protect civil rights, build solidarity in the movement, and
remunerate the victims of Cointelpro. There will also be
workshops on women in the BPP, the difference between the
BPP and the New BPP, and a number of workshops focusing on
Youth. There will be some closed sessions dealing with issues
pertinent to former Panthers.

Historic photo displays will be open the public and will include
over 60 photographs covering the early development of the Black
Panther Party through 1975. There will also be an exhibit of the
Black Panther Party Newspaper which at one time produced more
than 150,000 copies a week, and an exhibit of the New York Panther
Paper "Right On" There will be an ongoing film-video festival during
the entire conference with many topical films regarding the history
of the black Panther Party, political prisoners, Cointelpro and the
movement in general. Saturday evening, April 20, there will be a
buffet dinner reception, an opportunity to socialize and visit with
old friends and comrades.

This is an opportunity for older, more experienced activists to share
their knowledge and experience with young, enthusiastic activists of
today. It is also an opportunity for isolated activists in related fields
to come together to share creative and practical resources in the
fight for social justice.

We invite all former Panthers, community workers and current and
former activists in the cause of social justice to attend. For more
information and to download a registration form, please visit our
website: itsabouttimebpp.com
For more info: It's About Time, PO Box 221100, Sacramento, CA 95822
Phone: (916) 455-0908, e-mail: itsabouttime3@...
The It's About Time Committee is a 501(c)3 non-profit corporation.
Tax deductible donations can be made to help sponsor the Reunion and
Conference, to support publication of our newsletter or for Books
Behind Bars, a program that sends reading materials to prisoners
throughout the country.

Workshops - 35th year Reunion Conference

Building Solidarity - Facilitated by Elbert "Big Man" Howard
A discussion on international influence and support for the BPP and
the importance of building alliances with other groups

Differences between the Black Panther Party and the so-called
new black panther party - Facilitated by JoNina Abron and Ron Scott

Marxist - Leninist Theory and the Black Panther Party - Facilitated
by Cappy Pinderhughes

Cointelpro - Facilitated by Roz Payne
A discussion with documentation of the FBI's illegal operation to
discredit and destroy progressive organizations, especially the Black
Panther Party

Reparations - Facilitated by N'COBRA
Several workshops covering all various aspects of the Reparations movement

Police Brutality and the Protection of Civil Liberties - Facilitated by
members of Oct. 22 and ACLU

Women in the Struggle - Facilitated by Rosemary Mealy and others
Several workshops dealing with women's role in and contributions to the
movement

Mumia Abu-Jamal - Facilitated by Pam Africa and Mumia's attorney

Economics - Facilitated by William Brown and Stretch Peterson
A discussion of building economic stability in the community

Angola 3 Update - Facilitated by Robert King Wilkerson and Althea
Francois

Labor Organizing - Facilitated by Cleo Silvers
A look at various aspects of organizing labor today

Organizing Youth - Facilitated by Khalil Shayid, Ameejill Jackson and
Leslie Jones - Multiple workshops dealing with many aspects of
empowering youth in the struggle including a Youth - Elders Panel

The Historical Legacy of George Jackson and the Prison Movement -
Facilitated by Dr. Lynch, Dorsey Nunn and David Johnson

Post ID:2667
Sender:"benjamin ramos" <uriyoan@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-13 01:11:15
Subject:More on Vieques Political Prisoners!!
Message:

Vieques protesters sentenced; trespasses not 'justified'

By MANUEL ERNESTO RIVERA
Associated Press

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (April 10, 2002 10:48 p.m. EDT) - Five
members of Puerto Rico's pro-independence party were sentenced
to 30 days in a federal detention center Wednesday for breaking
into U.S. Navy property to protest bombing exercises on Vieques
island.

The five women were detained after breaking though Navy fences
on April 1, when Navy planes resumed dropping inert bombs
on the island's firing range after a pause of several months.

The five did not mount defenses to their trespassing charges
because they say they don't recognize the federal court's
authority in the U.S. territory.

"Vieques is the most open and painful wound of our country,"
Maria de Lourdes Santiago, leader of the five and vice president
of the Puerto Rican Independence Party, said before her sentencing.
She said the situation illustrates "what it means to live
in a country where others rule."

The five - also including Irma Rodriguez, Maria Elena Negron,
Mirna Rodriguez and Maribel Arroyo - will receive credit
for time already served in jail.

Handing down the sentences, Judge Salvador Casellas said
he respected the defendants' ideology, but "in my opinion
the acts of civil disobedience that have occurred in Vieques
at this moment aren't justified."

He said that because the United States is at war, Puerto
Ricans as U.S. citizens have "a responsibility" to support
national defense.

The judge also denied bail on Wednesday for five members
of the Socialist Movement group who were detained on Navy
lands this week, ordering them held until their trials are
scheduled.

Opponents of the Navy exercises say they harm the environment
and the health of Vieques' 9,100 residents. The Navy denies
that claim.

Although the protests have been muted since the Sept. 11
terrorist attacks, small bands of demonstrators have held
protests during the current round of exercises, which could
last up to three weeks. On Wednesday, no new arrests were
reported as U.S. warplanes dropped inert bombs on the firing
range.

Puerto Rico's small pro-independence party makes up only
one part of the opposition to Vieques training. Gov. Sila
Calderon, who supports the island's current commonwealth
status, also says the Navy should halt exercises.

Since maneuvers began April 1 on the outlying island, more
than a dozen people have been detained. The Navy says 13
sailors and Marines have been injured by protesters throwing
rocks and other objects. The demonstrators say their protests
have been peaceful.

President Bush says the Navy will leave by 2003. The Navy
says it is looking for alternative training sites.
---------------------------------------------------------------
This article is protected by copyright and should
not be printed or distributed for anything except
personal use.

You can find this story on the web at:
http://www.nandotimes.com/nation/story/355022p-2891390c.html

Subject:elected school board activists' trial 10am, fri apr19
Message:

2 witness statements:

To whom it may concern:

I was sitting in the auditorium at New Brunswick High School waiting for the 
Board members to return from their private session.  I heard a voice saying, 
"Please, don't touch me."  I turned toward the back of the auditorium, I saw 
Cliff Smith standing in the aisle with his hands behind his back clasped 
together.  Surrounding him were security guards saying to Cliff, "You have 
to leave the building."  The security guards were pushing him towards the 
door.  Cliff kept saying, "Please, don't touch me."  I saw the security 
guards slam Cliff Smith against the entrance door of the auditorium and 
pushed him outside the door.  His hands were still clasped behind his back.  
At that moment the Board returned to the auditorium.  I heard a disturbance 
in the hallway.  I saw Mrs. Moody, NBHS attendence officer, walk down the 
aisle of the auditorium toward the stage.  She returned with Mr. Embrey, the 
principal of NBHS. They walked outside of the auditorium toward the voices.

Beverly Marshall
President, New Brunswick Apartments Tenants' Association


To whom it may concern:

In honor so that the truth comes to light, I would like to testify my 
rendition of what I was a witness to of events that occured on the night of 
January 15th circa the time of 7:15 pm at New Brunswick High School.

Having a clear view as I sat within the central seating section of the 
institution's auditorium in attendance of a public meeting held by the New 
Brunswick Board of Education, on this night, I witnessed Cliff Smith, an 
individual that I have seen at several of these meetings within the same 
setting and have grown to hold conversations of a delicate educational 
nature, held a fervor converation with one Mr. Pierre Embrey, principal of 
the institution to which my daughters attend.  The conversation escalated 
due to the fact that Mr. Cliff Smith was passing out literature with the 
school's results of state mandatory examination.  I was able to observe that 
Mr. Embrey had in his hands papers, which he tried to give to Mr. Cliff 
Smith and Mr. Smith rose his hands high in the air as Mr. Embrey forced them 
upon his person and down his shirt.  Mr. Embrey told Mr. Smith to leave and 
forced him out of the auditorium using the aid of security guards although 
he did not resist.  After he was thrown out of the auditorium all we saw 
heard him exclaim was the fact that he was in a public meeting.

Next Mr. Embrey and Donald Bowling proceeded to take out Mr. Smith's brother 
Joe Smith out of the auditorium with brute force and throwing him up against 
the wall.  While Mr. Donald Bowling held him crucified up against the wall 
and repeatedly proceeded to push him repeatedly which caused him to hit his 
head several times against the wall.  Then Mr. Joe Smith was thrown to the 
ground and held had his neck under massive pressure from the force applied 
to it by Mr. Embrey's knee as evident from the screaming exhibited by Mr. 
Joe Smith.  Mr. Embrey then went into Mr. Joe Smith's pocket and retrieved a 
cellular phone stating would confiscate it because Mr. Joe Smith had been 
making bomb threats to the school.  Mr. Smign said it was his personal phone 
and that Embrey had no right to take it.  The police arrived and Mr. Joe 
Smith left with the authorities without contest.

I hold everything written in this letter to be the truth and self-evident.  
I cannot certify any previous actions by the Smiths that would have provoked 
this event.  However, their behavior was nothing but passive while Mr. 
Embrey and Mr. Donald Bowling exhibited in my opinion what would be an abuse 
of authority through aggressive behavior with loose cannon composure.

Attentively,

Ivan Salazar
President, Bilingual Parents' Association of New Brunswick

Douglass College Government Association elections will be held in the
Douglass College Center on Tuesday, April 16 and Wednesday, April 17. The
DCGA, the democratically-elected, student-controlled student government
organization of Douglass College, has the power to represent students to
administrators at the College and the University, carry student voices to
the state and the nation, organize students for action, and provide funding
and allocations to all student organizations.

As such, progressive members of DCGA have committed to running on a
ticket--the DOUGLASS UNITED ticket--dedicated to organizing and acting to
win student democracy at the University and real democracy within the city
of New Brunswick. We are dedicated to a twelve-point platform:
1. Defend Cultural Studies and Academics--Fight the Budget Cuts!
2. Stand Against Tuition Hikes
3. Increase and improve Cultural Programs and Centers
4. Justice in Funding and Allocations
5. Smash Oppression
6. Support and Value the Traditions of Douglass
7. Fight for Student Democracy
8. Sponsor Live Programs and Parties
9. Better General Services
10. Improve Recruitment and Retention
11.Unite Campus and Community
12. Support Women's Services

We are running a full slate of candidates in the DCGA elections, for all
positions--every Douglass United candidate will have "Douglass United"
printed by her name on election ballots! If you are interested in supporting
a campaign for justice and ensuring that student government is strongly
representative of student concerns and struggle, VOTE DOUGLASS UNITED!

Private Groups Get 42 Schools in Philadelphia

April 18, 2002 

By JACQUES STEINBERG


 

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 - In what is believed to be the
largest experiment in privatization mounted by an American
school district, a state panel charged with improving the
Philadelphia public school system voted tonight to transfer
control of 42 failing city schools to seven outside
managers, including Edison Schools Inc. and two
universities. 

The three members of the School Reform Commission appointed
by Gov. Mark Schweiker voted for the plan, while the two
members appointed by Mayor John F. Street voted against it.
The vote capped a fiery three-hour meeting in which the two
sides had split over whether Edison, the nation's largest
for-profit operator of public schools, had the capacity and
know-how to improve the 20 schools that it was assigned. 

"I want this reform to succeed," Michael Masch, a vice
president at the University of Pennsylvania and one of the
mayor's two appointees to the panel, said at one point in
the debate. "I am gravely concerned that the magnitude of
the change being proposed is imprudent." 

Moments later, James P. Gallagher, the president of
Philadelphia University and one of the governor's three
appointees, said, "We should push the envelope and be as
aggressive as possible." 

The panel's vote today represents a milestone in the
decade-long growth of the movement to turn troubled public
schools over to private operators. There is no better index
of the impact of this effort than Edison's own expansion:
over the last six years, it has gone from operating a
handful of public schools to more than 130 in 22 states,
with a combined student population that is larger than all
but a few dozen urban districts. 

All told, the Philadelphia panel voted to assign an outside
manager to one of every six schools in the city. In
addition to Edison, the other organizations involved
include two colleges that are in Philadelphia: Temple
University, which was assigned five schools, and the
University of Pennsylvania, which received three schools. 

The panel also tapped four other companies with various
degrees of school administrative experience, though each
was smaller than Edison. They are Chancellor Beacon
Academies Inc., a for-profit company based in Florida that
operates public and private schools (assigned five
schools); Foundations Inc., a nonprofit organization in
Philadelphia that offers after-school programs (four
schools); Victory Schools Inc., a New York-based company
that opened the state's first charter school (three
schools); and Universal Companies, a new venture begun by
the record producer Kenny Gamble (two schools). 

How much responsibility those managers would be given in
the schools that they have been assigned remains to be
negotiated with the state panel, as well as with the
teachers' union and the parents in those schools. But panel
officials said that, in many instances, the outsiders would
likely make sweeping changes in school curriculum, as well
as seek to replace school administrators and many of the
teachers. 

After the meeting, Jerry Jordan, a vice president of the
Philadelphia Federation of Teachers, said he regretted that
the panel had said so little about how the schools would be
redesigned by the outsiders. 

"They didn't spell anything out," Mr. Jordan said. "It's
like, `Let's see what works.' It shows a total lack of
respect." 

After the roll was called, several dozen student
protesters, who have long argued that it was undemocratic
for a for-profit company to operate a public school,
chanted, "Shame!" and "I am not for sale!" 

Beginning at daybreak, those same protesters had succeeded
in shutting down the system's Art Deco administrative
building on Benjamin Franklin Parkway by forming a
barricade at the entrance. Neither police officers nor the
building's 350 employees were willing to cross the line. As
a result, the meeting, which had been scheduled for 1 p.m.
at district headquarters, was delayed for two hours then
was moved to the city's African American Museum, nearly a
mile away. 

Today's developments were the most significant here since
late December, when Mr. Schweiker, a Republican, assumed
control of the city school system, which had been operated
by a board of education appointed entirely by Mr. Street, a
Democrat. At the time, Mr. Schweiker said that only a bold
approach could save a system in which more than half of the
nearly 200,000 students had failed to achieve minimum
proficiency on state reading and math tests. 

The governor had also made clear at the time that he wanted
Edison, which operates more than 130 public schools in 22
states, to play a major role in Philadelphia. Though the 20
schools that the company was awarded today was more than
double the number it manages in any other district, the
assignment was far more modest than the 60 Philadelphia
schools that it said it was capable of managing. 

Indeed, the governor had once argued that Edison should
assume control of the system's central administration.
Later, he retreated in the face of opposition from many
parents and students, as well as the teachers' union and
other labor groups representing school employees. They
questioned Edison's academic and financial record. 

At a news conference, James P. Nevels, the panel's
chairman, said of Edison's role, "Things have not turned
out as one would have expected." 

Still, a majority of the panel members managed to pass a
school reform plan in Philadelphia today that was more
ambitious than those mounted in any other district. 

The largest such plan previously was believed to have been
in Hartford, where all 32 schools in the district were
given over to the company Education Alternatives Inc. for
less than two years in the mid-1990's. But largely because
the Hartford experience failed relatively quickly, other
districts have usually embarked on more modest experiments,
with Edison now operating nine schools in Chester-Upland,
Pa., outside Philadelphia, and seven in Clark County, Nev.,
the Las Vegas district. 

In addition to the 42 schools that the Philadelphia panel
assigned to outside managers, it also ordered that 28 other
schools undergo substantial reorganization, with some
becoming more independent charter schools but most
remaining within direct control of the district. In the
cases of the schools identified today for private
intervention, the panel reserved the right to revoke a
contract in instances where the schools fail to improve.

Gelpi of the federal district court in Puerto Rico.  Gelpi also
sentenced attorney Hiram Lozada P�rez, President of the Civil Rights
Commission of the Puerto Rican Bar Association, to four (4) months in

hundred days in jail.  Gelpi additionally imposed fines on them.

range in Vieques. As he has done with other protesters, Gelpi's

leaders of the Vieques peace movement have also received absurdly
lengthy prison sentences, for example, Vieques Mayor Damaso Serrano

BELOW IS A STATEMENT WRITTEN BY ANTONIO CAMACHO NEGRON ON HIS RELEASE
______________________________________________________________________
Dear Compatriots:

This afternoon I do not find myself physically close to all of you, but my 
heart, my thoughts and my words are with you during this commemoration of 
the birth of Juan Antonio Corretjer.  Because I have sent a written message, 
  I will be brief.

As all of you know, I have rejected, time and again, every attempt by the 
government of the United States to criminalize our legitimate right to 
struggle for our independence by the recognized avenues afforded us
by our high moral standards, history and international law.

I have repeatedly denounced colonialism and a conditional freedom and 
consistent with this I have also rejected the conditional freedom that the 
United States government has sought to impose upon me in the
same manner in which I reject the conditional freedom under which our Puerto 
Rican homeland suffers.

On May 9th two-thirds of my sentence will be done.  According to the laws of 
the empire my release is mandatory.  Because I continue to reject any type 
of conditions for this supposed freedom, the government of the United States 
will hold me until May 20th with the purpose of having me report to the 
Federal Building in Puerto Rico.  I completely reject that condition.

I invite you to join me in front of the Federal Building (in Puerto Rico) on 
May 22nd at noon, not to sign for my freedom, but to reaffirm our freedom 
and our Puertoricanness.

Compatriots:

The independence of our homeland will not be a gift that is granted to us by 
the Congress of the  United States:  The independence of our homeland must 
be taken, we must win it.

Empires are not deities, they are structures lead by men and women.  They 
are omnipotent while there exist men and women that because of ignorance, 
opportunism or cowardice, surrender their souls and are
indifferent to its injustices and harm.

Don Pedro said:   "We do not have the arms to deal a blow to their naval 
forces, but we have the moral force to deal a blow to their reputation in 
the eyes of the world."

Many constantly repeat these words, but they are not empty words.  In this 
concept lies the key to our independence.

We who believe in the independence of our country, who grasp the urgency of 
becoming a free and sovereign nation have to bury defeatism and develop the 
aunthentic support of the majority.

We can not content ourselves with exercising some influences or to establish 
some goals.  Even less should we find satisfaciton in the electoral carnival 
that takes place every four years - suicidal faith in elections and our 
participatory collaboration in them - have robbed our people of the natural 
tendency to be free.

The present conditions favor us and call for us to become a minority for 
change; a minority is a force for transformation. A minority will be an 
authentic support of the majority.

The Sovereignty, dignity and liberty of our people cannot be conditioned by 
fear, by myopic interests, opportunism or ignorance, even if it comes from 
the majority.  The banners of freedom, sovereignty and dignity of the people 
have never first been championed by the broad masses.  It has always been a 
minority that through its example of persistance, love, sacrifice and 
courage, has brought the masses to embrace these ideals.

Independentistas, are not a majority but we are the legitimate 
representatives of the freedom and dignity of our homeland.  More than a 
duty we have to ourselves, it is our responsibility to the men and women who 
have given their lives or have dedicated them to this sacred ideal.  More 
so, it is our responsibility to future generations and to humanity itself.

To struggle for independence is to struggle for the highest universal values 
of justice, dignity, sovereignty and liberty.  And while there exists even 
one colony in the world, these values will be contested. Humanity has paid a 
very dear price for these and will can not and will not betray them.

Let us remember our compatriots!

" We do not have the arms to deal a blow to the naval forces, but we have 
the moral force to deal a blow to their reputation in the eyes of the 
world."

This is their achilles heal.
This is our challenge.

Thank you all.

Antonio Camacho Negron
#03587-069
P.O. Box 2000
White Deer, PA 17887

Dear Compatriots:

heart, my thoughts and my words are with you during this commemoration of

the empire my release is mandatory.  Because I continue to reject any type

Federal Building in Puerto Rico.  I completely reject that condition.

Thank you all.

Antonio Camacho Negron

to POP,
on behalf of the new brunswick peoples campaign, i must state that we are 
very disappointed with the lack of POP's involvement in newark's may 14 
election.

one would think that an organization with such "Progressive" positions would 
jump at the chance to work to elect ras baraka. there will be earl faisons 
until the cows come home unless we organize these communities to win 
political power. all those rallies become meaningless without political 
direction. political direction exists in the baraka campaign for council 
At-Large, but yet POP is satisfied with just the rally/march/lobbying?

yes we know, we have seen hamm here & hamm there at baraka events - but hamm 
is not POP & POP is not there.

how can POP demand community police control boards for newark, but not 
actively support the candidate that CAN WIN & will draft up this 
legislation? why is POP going to lobby trenton about police misconduct &tc., 
when those positions can be implemented here in newark?

nbpc proposes that POP immediately put all resources toward electing ras 
baraka on may 14. push back the trenton lobby date of may 15 and do the much 
needed work to elect ras baraka. this is a formal proposal, there is still 
time -
tic...

i remember in '98 hungerford/henson was a point person of the baraka 
campaign, among many other activities he brought me lunch on election day 
from baraka headquaters and drove me to diffent polling sites. now we see an 
organization from new brunswick put forward a better effort to elect ras 
baraka than POP? what should people think about this?

joe smith
New Brunswick Peoples Campaign 2002
Unite the Many, Defeat the Few!

                                        bombed

                             To stay home that day

Millions of Italians Take to the Streets in a General Strike

April 17, 2002 

By MELINDA HENNEBERGER


In the first daylong general strike in 20 years, millions of
Italian workers protested the conservative government's
plans to create a more flexible labor market.

>      "NAME YOUR OWN PRICE" for Theatre Tickets on Tuesday, April 23
>
>A glorious sympohy of stories about our town...  tales of murder and
>arson; a baby saved and a baby lost; an impossible love between a free
>man and an enslaved woman; and three silver spoons that haunt a family
>for four generations... all come together under the embracing branches
>of Joyce Kilmer's immortalized tree.
>
>Inspired by the personal testimonies of present day New Brunswick area
>residents, PUBLIC GHOSTS-PRIVATE STORIES is a beautifully woven tapestry
>of over one hundred and eight years of Hispanic, Hungarian, Irish and
>African-American life in our town.
>

>complementary modes of work or just be ignored.
>
>As a member of POP, an organization that I suspect is allied with or at 
>least
>has coals in common with NBPC,  I suggest that a positive approach relying 
>on
>the merits of the substance of your suggestion would be much more effective
>than personal and organizational attacks that denigrate the  complementary
>work that we do. Only the fifth paragraph of your e-mail contains a 
>positive
>proposal.
>
>Why did you take such an approach? Why can't we acknowledge complementary
>efforts? If there is disagreement about priorities, why can't they be aired
>without sarcasm and disdain. If there is a good argument for a particular 
>appr
>oach, then use that argument without denigrating others' priorities? Why 
>not
>urge, encourage and support the work of allied organizations? An approach
>that is not an attack is more likely to change people's minds. We have 
>enough
>common adversaries. Let's treat each other's allied organizations with
>courtesy and respect.
>
>On a substantive level, do you know the efforts that POP has made to 
>support
>Ras Baraka or what plans we have to do so? Have you spoken with him and his
>campaign about POP's involvement? If he wants more help or you think we
>should do more, then it is much more effective to ask for help in the work
>that needs to be done than to brag that your organization has done more? 
>Why
>not tell us what you have been doing and suggest ways that we add to 
>existing
>efforts?
>
>I am, myself, particularly "disappointed" that you would choose to 
>criticize
>the attention that POP has paid to the Faison case and the Faison family, 
>for
>several reasons.  I suggest that we need to tend to the needs of 
>individuals,
>because individuals need support in our society, individual struggles help 
>us
>understand systemic problems better, and such actions best demonstrate our
>underlying humanity.
>
>I agree that political direction is also necessary.
>
>I suspect that people in POP will pass by the unconstructive elements of 
>your
>e-mail, cut to the chase, and think about what we could and should be doing
>to help Ras. I certainly intend to bring up the substantive issue at
>Thursday's  meeting this week. So I hope that this e-mail will not spawn a

Post ID:2696
Sender:"peoples campaign" <nbpc_2002@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-22 16:17:23
Subject:Fwd: Re:  POP proposal
Message:

>From: makemba@...

Some people will say and do anything for a free lunch.

I must give my comments here.   And let me be very clear and upfront
in saying that I am not speaking for the organization right now.

It is not your suggestion per se that I object to, for I am always
open  to hearing suggestions from concerned people in the
community about things POP can and should
be doing.   What I object to is your arrogant and condescending
attitude that is thinly disguised as a suggestion.  And quite frankly,
you ain't got no reason to be arrogant or condescending!

As an individual member of POP I could personally give a hoot
as to whether or not your organization is satisfied with the work that
I do!   To put it bluntly --  I don't do things for the sake of impressing
people who live outside of my community.

I have seen this attitude before from certain people who live way outside of
this community.
They come around here with their little superior acting attitudes
and then think they are going to put people in this community down because
they don't think as they do!

I could go ON AND ON AND ON about the things I don't see your organization
doing!


People in POP have been fighting hard and have been on
the front line of these issues!   And we are comprised of
people who share many different ideologies that don't allow
are differences to get in the way of what we must do.

And POP was one of the first organizations to start to become
very vocal about issues that other organizations in NJ did not
want to touch!

Furthermore, people in POP LIVE THESE ISSUES ! ! !
We take a personal hands on approach with our community.
We don't just sit around and intellectualize and theorize about
things!

One of the main problems with the progessive movement in
this country is that there are those who LIVE it and there are
those for which this is a fad -- something "in" to do!   There are
those who can change their affiliations and ideas just as they are
changing their clothes.  When it's no longer vogue to belong to
the progressive movement they can just drop things and go right
back into their communities and get their nice jobs and call it
a day!  History proves me true on this point.

I remember about  a little over 10 years people were
talking about how they weren't liberal.   I don't recall anybody too much
talking about being liberal back in the 80's and 90's.
Then it simply wasn't fashionable for many
to be affiliated with progressive causes.

In fact back in 1991 when I was victimized by police brutality,
I couldn't find people who wanted to hear about it.  I had a difficult
enough time finding people locally.   And forget about finding
anyone who lived outside of this area!

I hope we won't see that trend again within the progressive movement!

So here's some advice.  Before you began to want to criticize others
make sure you look inward first.

Personally, I think your comment about your free lunch was very revealing.

Lisa Davis



New Brunswick Peoples Campaign 2002
Unite the Many, Defeat the Few!

By Dan Balz and Dana Milbank

Sender:whcoon@...
Post Date/Time:2002-04-25 22:07:57
Subject:The Green Party not Wasting Resources
Message:

First of all, Mr.Smith, the Green Party is not wasting money on federal and state elections. In 2000, if Ralph Nader has recieved 5% of the popular vote, the Green Party of the United States would have recieved federal money for the 2004 Presidetnal Elections. This would have given the 2004 Presidental Nominee the opptunity to boardcast on Television, Radio, and major Newspapers arguments for incrasing the minimum wage to 11 dollars per hour (what the United States Department of Labor states is the amount needed for a person to live in the United States without health care. 
      Speaking of Health Care, The GPUS would have the oppotunity to raise the issue of Univeral Health Care and Child Care. Arguments could be heard on why and how to clean the air, waterways, and land from short-term and long-term toxic chemicals, and how to replace an economy based on oil to an economy based on renewable energies, such as solar and wind power. 
      Neither President Bush or Al Gore stated that they wished to do this things. Research the NY Times arcivies at your local library to read Bush's or Gore's speeches at their conventions, or on the campaign trails. 

      Now, on the state level. In New Jersey, if a political party recieves 10% of the total general assembly vote, then that party recieves ballot access (i.e. not having to stand in front of supermarkets to get a candidate on the ballot.), and it able to hold primaries if they so desire (21 State Green Parties, including California, New York, Texas, and Minnoseta, have ballot status). This would be a very democratic way for elections to held, a choice between at least three canddiates instead of two, what a wonderful thing!
      
      Finally, there is a Green Party in every state in the USA and in most countries around the world. We have suceeded in gaining seats in German, French, and English parliaments (to name a few). We have had state assemblypersons in California, and will continue to do so among the rest of the states in the great country. If the Democratic Party claims we cost them elections, then their canddiate should be one that makes any Green Party candidate obselete. Please use the non-partasian websites WWW.OPENSECRETS.ORG and WWW.VOTE-SMART.ORG to see how many Democratic candidates are funded, in many cases, by the same money the Republican Party is funded with. I hope you use this knowledge.
                                           Peacefully,
                                                `Ray Higbee

UNITY & STRUGGLE �BULLETIN ����4 /19/02


The Trojan Horse

Communists & REVOLUTIONARY DEMOCRATS understand that there can be no 
socialist revolution without the completion of the Democratic Revolution. 
(See Lenin, Mao). They also know that the Revolutionaries must take the lead 
in the completion of a Democratic Revolution and even when utilizing the 
bourgeois instrument of Electoral Politics, must use it to forward the 
themes, the political lines, the ideological clarity of the revolutionary 
leaders of the Working Class.
For these reasons Revolutionaries running in bourgeois elections never 
consider Only their own candidacy, but take in to consideration the critical 
needs and issues of the working class. If they narrow their view to consider 
Only their own election to a seat, and do not put out the issues and themes 
that affect the whole working class, then they have become somewhat 
politically retarded so that their "insurgency" is reduced to the narrow 
career considerations of the petty bourgeois democrat !
In the Newark elections of May 14, Ras Baraka and in the alliance with the 
Puerto Rican north ward candidate, Hector Corchado, are without a doubt the 
most progressive force in the election. The very political strength and 
democratic leadership that their alliance has projected "Black-Latino Unity" 
draws the entire mass base of the grassroots constituency together, in 
defiance of the bogus "teams" both mayoral candidates have projected which 
excludes both Baraka and Corchado.
This theme is especially relevant and necessary because of the betrayals to 
this unity which were demonstrated in the New York City and Los Angeles 
Mayoral contests where Black & Latino Bourgeois Democratic politicians 
sabotaged that unity so that both Latino Mayoral candidates were defeated 
and so called "moderate" whites �were elected. Bloomberg in NYC spent 59 
million and bought colored quislings on the spot. Hahn in LA using the beard 
of his father's bravery in meeting Dr. King at the airport, and his palm 
greasing of Negro politicians, zig zagged his way into office, and upon 
being elected immediately announced that he was firing the Black Police 
Chief. Now the Negroes are whining, betrayal. But it was their betrayal 
which allowed Hahn's.
In Newark, some people believe that as long as they vote for RAS BARAKA and 
HECTOR CORCHADO, they have fulfilled their progressive obligations so that 
they can covertly vote for the Wall St Trojan Horse, Corey Booker. But this 
is simply a failure to closely examine and analyze the entire meaning of 
this campaign.
On one hand you have Sharpe James, in public office since the Community's 
Choice Campaign of 1970. He is part of the Afro American National 
Bourgeoisie. Always compromising with Corporate Capital, usually shaky in 
confronting the big dogs of government and business. an important operative 
in the Democratic Party, usually self hypnotized by the beauties of his ego, 
never completely honest, manipulative, capable of any trick, betrayal, scam 
one can think of.
Yet he is the national bourgeoisie, as shaky as Chiang Kai Chek, and on site 
representative of the self promoting Tonto politics of the congressional 
black caucus, though there are a few exceptions. But the National 
Bourgeoisie for all its weak wavering dishonest compromise is a flawed but 
actual representative of "Home Rule", a very weak example of this city's 
Self Determination. That it is so weak must also raise questions of the 
weakness of Newark's would be revolutionaries.
Corey Booker, on the other hand, is a Comprador, straight out. He has raised 
earlier, 795,000 from Wall St. (See Star Ledger, NYTimes) and another 
400,000 from New Jersey suburbs! �Now that figure is nearly three million 
dollars! Including contributions from Goldman- Sachs Brokerage, Jack Kemp, 
the National Republican party, &C . With over One Million dollars raised 
from Outside Newark,
It indicates that those are his true sponsors and backers.
In addition, Booker is an active Republican. Yes, the Republicans of Bush, 
Ashcroft, Thomas, Whitman, budget cuts, tax rebates to the corporations, 
Enron, World Trade Center suspiciousness, Afghanistan, Enablers of Sharon's 
Massacre Crusade of the Palestinians, Spy plane over China, Confederate 
Flag, Environmental Terror, Right wing election crooks, &c &C
Booker escorted �Bush 2's Spouse Laura, Republican Senate Candidate Bob 
Franks and the super rightist Gubernatorial candidate Bret Schundler through 
Newark. Booker backs Privatization, Charter Schools, the general Republican 
anti -working class anti -minority anti -immigrant , pro corpora-e Agenda. 
He is quite simply a Trojan horse for the Republican initiative to take 
Newark, now that they have been kicked out of Trenton.
For the people of Newark, a Republican victory would mean the Destruction of 
the Public School System, The Privatization of the businesses and resources 
that will come from the building of the Arena, the privatization of the 
entire so called Newark Renaissance. Ironically, when Booker claims to be 
calling for the benefits of this renaissance to be spread among the whole 
Newark Community not just for Downtown. We must realize Booker Is Downtown. 
A representative of Corporate Republican Interests . They are his Sponsors, 
not the people of Newark!
If Booker's Economic base is Right Wing Corporate , his social base is the 
suburban Yuppies and Buppies who form the majority of his staff. His triumph 
would mean the Elimination of 16,000 jobs from the City Hall Infra structure 
and staffs. These jobs would then be refilled by the suburban white Yuppie 
and Buppie Negro contingent, already easing in with NJPAC, and city hall's 
offices would become almost instantly "foreign" i.e., the other part of the 
middle management largely white college crowd who will also be the �staff 
for the new businesses coming into the city. The young folks who the new 
downtown condominiums are being built!
It is as simple as Home Rule Vs Foreign Domination. �Self Determination Vs 
Corporate Rule! Mao made a United Front with Chiang Kai Chek's Kuomintang 
against the Japanese Imperialists, but when the Japanese were defeated 
Chiang tried to destroy the Revolutionaries led by Mao , but were defeated 
and run out of China.
So that the clear task of Revolutionaries in Newark is to Elect Ras Baraka 
and Hector Corchado, not by copying the Opportunism of the bourgeois 
candidates but putting out a clear Revolutionary Democratic Line. E.g. 
DEMOCRACY & SELF DETERMINATION- 1END STATE TAKEOVER OF EDUCATION-
2RESTORE NEWARK CITIZENS RIGHT TO SPEAK AT CITY COUNCIL MEETINGS- 3COMMUNITY 
CONTROL OF POLICE- 4REDUCE DRUGS AND CRIME BY MASSIVE CAMPAIGN FOR JOBS, 
EDUCATION AND RECREATION- 5 TO MAKE NEWARK'S "RENAISSANCE" CITY WIDE 
&-REBUILD THE ECONOMY - STRESS COOPERATION BETWEEN THE PEOPLE OF NEWARK, 
CITY & STATE AND COUNTY GOVERNMENT, BIG AND SMALL BUSINESS, & INSTITUTIONS 
&C

If the Political Line is �clear & strong enough and distributed broadly with 
the necessary outreach to the community , the grass roots and indigenous 
people of Newark, Ras Baraka's Campaign, as well as the Baraka-Corchado 
Black-Latino Unity ticket, �will be successful. �But the Campaign must be an 
example of Revolutionary Democratic Organization and Mobilization not just 
career building with the present campaign, but as a method of Organizing the 
whole working class for the broader struggle against Imperialism & National 
Oppression. Against War and Rising Fascism!
True Revolutionaries cannot turn their backs on the need to defeat the Right 
Wing Assault. But certainly, Booker will be back in 2006, some analysts 
think that is his real battlefield. That the present campaign is just 
advertising for the real Armageddon, �Booker's backers know that after the 
present Mayor is gone, the next candidate representing Newark's people might 
be an actual Revolutionary.

Hey Joe,

If you're planning on being a full-time cheerleader for the Democrats
I have a few suggestions for you.

First, join the CP-USA... they've been at it far longer than you. 
Maybe they could give you some pointers in mainstream brown-nosing.

Second, Clinton bombed Yugoslavia, Sudan, and Iraq, expanded NATO,
raised the military budget, and repealed welfare.  Do you have some
reason to believe that his Democratic successor would have an
agenda that differed in the least bit in its goals than, as you
affectionately refer to him, "Bush 2"?

The ends are the same.  I prefer the "honesty" of the Bush 
administration, because at least it is doing its part to mobilize
and unite the opposition, instead of the bastards sitting at home
wondering why the "progressive" president they have elected is 
doing such nasty things.

Someday, you will join your brother in working for some government
floozy (if you're very, very lucky), and the angst that drives your 
politics will subside.  Those people whose convictions are based on 
their moral fiber, and not on post-adolescent anomie, will continue 
to build their organizations.  Not with instant self-gratification 
in mind, but with the thought of a more just and free society for 
their children and grandchildren if not for themselves.

I'm hoping you will unravel sooner than later.  You have polluted
this list and, indeed, the activist community with your hare-brained
rants for long enough.

Chris

Post ID:2715
Sender:"cliff smith" <cliffsmith69@...>
Post Date/Time:2002-04-26 20:12:21
Subject:rain on broadway
Message:

N.Y. revue to spotlight Rutgers students

Friday, April 26, 2002

BY BETTE SPERO
Star-Ledger Staff

Whatever Rutgers University's students at the Mason Gross School of the Arts 
in New Brunswick may accomplish in their show business careers, some soon 
can put a Broadway credit at the top of their r�sum�s.

On Sunday, Mason Gross students, along with fellow thespians from
alumni to professors, will present "Rutgers on Broadway" at the Majestic 
Theater in New York.

Their stage setting augurs well -- it's where "The Phantom of the Opera" 
plays (except on Sundays, that
show's day off).

"It's pretty exciting acting on a Broadway stage for the first time,"
says Michael Sorvino, 24, a Mason Gross graduate last year. "I hope it
isn't the last time I act on Broadway."

Sorvino, a Tenafly native, attended Mason Gross at the suggestion of
his father: actor Paul Sorvino. The elder Sorvino studied in New York
with acting coach William Esper, who has taught theater at Rutgers
for the past 25 years.

"It's a straightforward, truly usable acting program -- not a lot of 
baloney," says Michael Sorvino. "You get 'a good box of tools' and come out 
of there knowing how to work. The curriculum is comprehensive, everything 
from stage combat to stage management."

Sorvino said he leaned toward performing an original comic monologue on 
Sunday. He and a Mason Gross classmate, Ivan Sanchez, co-wrote a one-act 
play, "Coffee," for their senior project. "There's a novella in me 
somewhere," says Sorvino.

Esper is directing about 25 Mason Gross students in the 90-minute program of 
scenes from various plays and films. Rain Denise Wilson, who's receiving a 
master's degree in acting from Mason Gross on May 23, is one of them.

Wilson played Titania, queen of the fairies, in Shakespeare's "A Midsummer 
Night's Dream," which Esper staged at Rutgers this season. At the Majestic, 
she will perform a dramatic scene from the film, "Losing Isaiah," and a 
romantic scene from the play, "Jelly's Last Jam."

The actress, a Chicago native in her 20s, describes the master's program at 
Mason Gross as "three long, intense, beautiful years."

"This was the right place," she says. "After coming here, I'm so much more 
ready to get on with the business of acting. Can you imagine starting a 
career on Broadway?"

Esper says he's confident Rutgers fans would fill the 1,500-seat Majestic.

"We're adaptable," he says. "A lot of friends will be in the audience."

Alumni on stage will vary from Kristin Davis, a 1987 graduate who acts in 
the television show "Sex and the City," to Terrell Tilford, a 1998 graduate 
who played David Grant on the CBS daytime drama, "Guiding Light."

Avery Brooks, an illustrious Mason Gross alumnus and teacher, will act a 
scene from "Paul Robeson," Phillip Hayes Dean's drama about another famous 
Rutgers graduate. Brooks did the play in the 1980s at Crossroads Theatre 
Company in New Brunswick and on Broadway.

Brooks' television acting has ranged from playing Hawk on "Spenser: For 
Hire" (with the late Robert Urich) and "A Man Called Hawk" in the 1980s to 
portraying Commander Benjamin Sisko on "Star Trek: Deep Space Nine" in the 
1990s.

George B. Stauffer, dean of Mason Gross, began the practice last year of 
spotlighting Rutgers arts students annually in prestigious professional 
settings in New York. Then, the school's music students gave a sold-out 
concert in Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center.

"Our musicians performed for a packed house. They were a smashing success," 
says Stauffer. "We're equally optimistic this year. This is a chance to see 
future stars of stage and screen begin their professional careers and to 
celebrate artists who already are successful."

Rutgers on Broadway

Where: Majestic Theater, 247 W. 44th St., New York

When: 4 p.m. Sunday

How much: $15-$30. Call (732) 932-7511.

>agent provacatuers masquarading around as champions of the people
>whereas their main objective is to cause disharmony and disunity among
>progressive forces where ever they go!
>

>to sabotage the current civil rights and progressive movement
>that is amassing.   And they will use any and all means necessary.
>

>a progressive movement, but whose actions demonstrate
>that they are only trying to destroy it.
>

>extremely disdainful.
>
>As you are completely lacking in social skills, let me
>educate you about something.  There are certain unwritten
>social rules.   People within a group will
>make references to themselves in a certain way
>that is acceptable only if you are a member of
>the group.  When people outside of the group make
>those same references about the same group,
>the references have a completely different connotation
>and are unacceptable.
>A White person making a reference about a "redneck"
>has a completely different connotation then when
>a Black person uses the word "redneck."  I've been
>among Italian people, Jewish people, Homosexual people, etc.
>that referred to themselves in ways that I understood
>I could never do because I am not a member of
>that group.
>
>I understood and respected that.  In my e-mails to you
>I never once used any word that anyone would construe
>as being racially offensive.  And neither has anyone
>else on this list serve for that matter.    I don't know where you get
>off thinking you can use any word you like when referring
>to people within a certain ethnic group.  You are not African American

>Are you getting my point here?  Are you getting my
>message on this one?

>Jersey

>the

>at
>ending the armed rule of the bourgeoisie over the ruling class.

>forget

year's March ON Trenton.-*-

>Adherents of the Democrats are free to say what they want about their 
>party.
>What they may not do is claim their devotion to it amounts to Marxism.
>
>Let us look at U&S' statement, "The Trojan Horse," about this year's Newark
>municipal election. It begins with this:
>
>Communists & REVOLUTIONARY DEMOCRATS understand that there can be no
>socialist revolution without the completion of the Democratic Revolution.
>(See Lenin, Mao)"
>
>The more important thing is unsaid: there is no democracy for the working
>class and the oppressed nationalities without revolution. (That was what
>Lenin and Mao were about.) The posture of democracy first, then socialism,
>is consistent throughout. It amounts to reformism, not Marxism.
>
>The antics of "Black & Latino Bourgeois Democratic politicians" in New York
>and Los Angeles are described as "betrayal" of the principle of 
>Black-Latino
>unity. They're not betraying their bourgeois "principles" of anything. The
>principle of multinational unity only has meaning for the oppressed on a
>working class basis. Nowhere in this piece is the class content of the
>principle explained.
>
>A list of Cory Booker's sins is described to prove he is--a Republican! The
>problem is that everything on the list is typical as well of Democrats,
>like, um . . . Cory Booker. The real Trojan horse against the people isn't
>just Booker, it's the whole Democratic Party. Sharpe James is also a
>Democrat. Why is he an alternative?
>
>The paper's assessment of Sharpe is accurate enough. The difference comes
>down to his wispy national bourgeois aspects. These mean absolutely nothing
>without the political self-activity of the masses. To put this unwarranted
>emphasis on James is outright subjection to bourgeois leadership. U&S must
>also be taxed with Joseph Smith's demands (don't try to disavow him, U&S!)
>that other groups should drop their own activities, like the May 15
>Statewide March Against Police Brutality, in favor of Newark election
>activity.
>
>The piece supports Ras Baraka's campaign. That is a different matter from
>James. A comparison is made with the united front against Japanese
>imperialism of the Communist Party of China and the Kuomintang party of the
>landlords and capitalists. The problem here is the piece doesn't justify 
>the
>comparison. (Mao said political power grows out of the barrel of a gun.
>That's exactly how the Communists later ran the Kuomintang out of
>continental China.)
>
>A number of "revolutionary democratic" program points are put forth. They
>are only revolutionary if put forth as class struggle. For example, the
>program of community control of the police is only revolutionary if aimed 
>at
>ending the armed rule of the bourgeoisie over the ruling class.
>
>Even so, no democratic program is in and of itself revolutionary. The
>democratic program is necessary to revolution, but not sufficient. The
>bourgeois state can never be overthrow by purely democratic means. To 
>forget
>this is to forget Marxism and fall into reformism.
>
>Nowhere does the paper's discussion of mass organization go beyond
>bourgeois-legal means. Most importantly, the need for a new and genuine
>Communist Party to lead the working class and the oppressed to proletarian
>revolution is ignored.
>
>Although this piece on its own makes almost no case for Ras, I hope to see
>him elected. Neither the stifling 1970 Old Guard nor the downtown/Booker 
>New
>Guard have anything to offer the great majority of Newark's residents. Ras
>will bring a new voice, he will raise considerable interest in the
>community. The only real test of what he can do with a seat on the Council
>will be what happens when he gets one.
>
>

Our last election for DCGA ended in a TIE for the position of Internal Vice
President! This illustrates ever more strongly that it is *vital* that
people turn out today to vote Kelly Brennan for Internal Vice President!
Polls are open at the Douglass College Center between 10 AM and 4 PM. Stop
by and cast your vote; one vote does make a difference!

Kelly Brennan is the DOUGLASS UNITED candidate for Internal Vice President.
She is committed to the Douglass United platform--fighting the budget cuts,
smashing all forms of oppression, valuing the traditions of Douglass
College, standing up for women's services, and struggling for student
democracy. As Class of 2005 president, she has worked in her class and in
DCGA to rectify women's body image issues on campus, and has refounded
CURVES (Combatting Un-Realistic Views of Eating and Size); she has, as a
member of the Presidential Search Action Committee, been actively involved
in standing for a strong student representation in the upcoming search for a
Rutgers University president. In addition, Kelly has taken a leading role in
fighting privatization at the University and in building a student-labor
alliance with maintenance and custodial workers. She has consistently
represented the interests of students with dedication and passion, and she
will bring this commitment to the position of Internal Vice President.

Vote Kelly Brennan!
Douglass United
Internal Vice President
TODAY, Monday, April 29
Douglass College Center
10 AM - 4 PM

Subject:RALLY AGAINST THE BUDGET CUTS! FOR AFFORDABLE EDUCATION!
Message:

Tomorrow, at 2:30 PM, on the steps of Brower Commons, the associated
Student Governing Associations of Rutgers--DCGA, LCGA, RCGA and CCC--will
sponsor a rally for affordable education and against the budget cuts. As
students at a public state university, we recognize the importance of the
mission of the public university--affordable, accessible, high-quality
education available to all. The university exists--or should exist--as a
resource for the people of the state, and must be valued as such. Instead,
however, it has come under attack--budgets repeatedly slashed and calls
for additional funding going unanswered as enrollment continues to
rise. We must make our voices heard! Tell Trenton that higher education
matters--

Tuesday, April 30
2:30 PM
Brower Commons
College Avenue Campus

Claridad Newspaper, April 19, 2002
By Carmelo Ruiz Marrero

University Professor Jose Solis Jordan, jailed by Federal authorities since 
1999 for allegedly being a terrorist, will be transfered to the Federal 
Prison in Guaynabo, Puerto Rico, by the end of April, according to 
information received from his wife Marta Gonzalez.  It is expected that on 
July 23, 2002, he will be released to a halfway house in Trujillo Alto, and 
that we will complete his sentence in November at which time he will be 
released to the community at large.

Solis Jordan, who taught at the Education Department of the Rio Piedras 
campus of the University of Puerto Rico, was found guilty by a federal jury 
on March 12, 1999, for allegedly placing a bomb outside an army recruitment 
center in Chicago in December of 1992. No one was killed or wounded in that 
blast.  At that time, Solis Jordan was working as a professor at the 
University of DePaul and was doing volunteer work at the Corretjer Puerto 
Rican Cultural Center, both also in Chicago.

Rafael Marrero, infiltrator and provacteur

The star witness of federal proesecutors was the undercover infiltrator and 
agent provacateur Rafale Marrero, who admitted during the trial to having 
placed the bomb in question and to having recieved immunity in addition to 
$119,000 dollars for his services for the F.B.I. Besides Marrero's testimony 
and the allegations of the F.B.I., prosecutors did not present any other 
evidence to substantiate their case.  It was the word of honor of the F.B.I. 
and that of one of its informants against the word of a Puerto Rican 
independentista accused of bombing a federal building.  The jury, that did 
not have even one Latino in it, and whose Chairwomen was an employee of the 
Justice Department, believed federal prosecutors.

Marrero was not an unknown to the independence movement or to the Puerto 
Rican community in Chicago. This individual made his "entrance" on the 
political scence in Puerto Rico during the 1980's, when he became a member 
of the Anti-Electoral Front where he worked to create divisions and internal 
conflicts.

A the end of the 1980's, Marrero, moved to Chicago, where he became active 
in the Puerto Rican community and gained the trust of the staff at the 
Corretjer Cultural Center. He agressively sought to become friends with the 
family and friends of the Puerto Rican political prisoners.  He then married 
Evelyn odriguez, sister of then political prisoners Ida Luz and Alicia 
Rodriguez.  He had a child with Evelyn Rodriguez who he named Alicia Luz in 
honor of the baby's two aunts.

At the Cultural Center, Marrero began to plant and promote discord amogn the 
staff,assumed ultra-leftist and hardline positions, as he tried to instigate 
his comrades to commit acts of violence. Marrero also begin a campaign to 
discredit Jose Lopez, Director of that institution.

It was at this time that Jose Solis Jordan and Marrero met, given that their 
wives were close friends.  In 1995 Solis Jordan and his family returned to 
Puerto Rico. In the meantime, Marrero "transformed" himself from an ultra 
sectarian revolutionary to a attack dog and enemy of anything that was done 
and said by the independence movement.

At that time, Marrero began to publish and distribute El Pito, a defamatory 
newsletter dedicated to slander the Puerto Rican community and its leaders, 
especially targetting Jose Lopez and U.S. Congressman Luis Gutierrez 
(D-Chicago).  The financial backers and supporters of El Pito, were the 
developers and real estate interests that sought to sell block by block the 
Puerto Rican community in Chicago to right whites.  Among these developers 
and realtors was Gloria Chevere, who has close ties to Carlos Romero 
Barcelo.

Political Intrigue

According to Jose Lopez and his collegues at the Cultural Center, Chevere 
and Romero Barcelo have channeled funds which in part have come from the 
financial backers of the PNP prostatehood party in Puerto rico, in order to 
finance the election campaigns of Congressman Gutierrez' opponents. Romero 
detests Gutierrez not only because he (Gutierrez) is an Independentista but 
alos because of his friendly ties to the Popular Democratic Party of Puerto 
Rico and because Gutierrez torpedoed the Young Bill in 1998.

In addition to using the El Pito newsletter as a anti-Puerto Rican platform, 
Marrero served as a source for a series of sensationalist articles that 
appeared in February of 1997 in the Chicago daily newspaper the Sun Times.  
In these articles it was alleged that in the Roberto Clemente School,in the 
Puerto Rican Community and affiliated to the Corretjer Cultural Center, 
students were indoctrinated with pro-independentista ideas and that some of 
its teachers were members of the FALN (Amed Forces for National 
Liberation,in English).

These "reports" motivated the State Legislature of Illinois to launch an 
investigation of the Roberto Clemente School, which was led by right-wing 
Representative Edgar Lopez, a declared enemy of the independence movement 
and of Luis Gutierrez.

The star witness of this investigation was none other than Marrero, who 
testified before legislators that the Clemente School was a hideout and den 
of terrorists and that the school was chanelling and using State and Federal 
funds to finance pro-independence propaganda and to support the campaign to 
free the Puerto Rican political prisoners.
But the investigation which was described by the Puerto Rican Community as a 
McCarthyist witch hunt, did not find evidence of even one illegal action at 
the Clemente School or the Puerto Rican Cultural Center

Imprisoned, but not defeated

Of the time that Solis Jordan was in jail the first few months were the 
worst because it was during this time that he was subjected to countless 
humiliations and indignities.  He was held for various weeks at the state 
peneteniary in Peoria, forced to sleep on the floor of a cell that was 
infested with rodens and was later transferred to the Federal Peniteniary in 
Coleman, Florida, where he is imprisoned today.  His first three weeks at 
Coleman were spent in solitary confinement and in chains 23 hours a day.

Once he was in general population at Coleman, he did not resort to cursing 
his bad luck, nor did he resign himself to the stuation, he kept busy by 
developing new projects and helping his fellow inmates.  Solis Jordan is 
presently giving G.E.D. Classes to other prisoners.  At first, the prison 
authorities assign to him about a dozen "troublemakers" or "incorregibles" 
to see what would happen.  After a few weeks, his classes were filled to 
capacity as more and more inmates wanted to participate in his classes.

In addition to lending a helping hand to any prisoner that requested it, 
often for things such as how to write a letter or to know their rights, he 
also is writing a book about investigative methodologies.

Solis is the father of 5 children.  Three of them are children of a previous 
marriage of his wifes, whose first husband died in a tragic accident.

Eight Inmates Die in Cells as Fire Races Through Jail

May 5, 2002 

By DAVID M. HALBFINGER


 

BAKERSVILLE, N.C., May 4 - Eight inmates were killed when a
cramped, outmoded jail here erupted in flames on Friday
night, billowing smoke so thick that rescuers were unable
even to unlock the prisoners' cells, the authorities said. 

The fire at the Mitchell County jail, here in the western
North Carolina hills not far from the Tennessee border,
also injured 13 people, including two sheriff's deputies
who crawled through the suffocating smoke, unlocked one
cell, and led eight inmates outside to safety. 

Sheriff Kenneth R. Fox said that state fire investigators
arrived today and had indicated that they believed the
fire, which burned for close to 90 minutes, had started
accidentally. He said it appeared to have started in a
brick and wood storage shed next to a small first-floor
holding cell used as a drunk tank. The shed held cleaning
equipment, wiring and a small electric heater, but the
sheriff said he did not believe the heater was in use at
the time. 

One inmate in that cell, Joey Grindstaff, 23, was killed,
Sheriff Fox said. The other seven men who died were trapped
in an upstairs cell. Mr. Grindstaff had been arrested on
Thursday or Friday after leading officers on a chase, the
sheriff said. 

Sheriff Fox said that although at least one of the dead,
who were aged 20 to 46, was awaiting trial on felony
charges, most were in on minor charges, and he described
several as "good boys." He said he was unable to provide
the exact charges most of the dead had been facing, their
addresses or survivors. 

One victim, Mark Thomas, 20, was serving a minor sentence -
the sheriff said he believed it was for driving while
intoxicated or a lesser offense - on weekends only, and was
to receive his high-school equivalency diploma next
weekend, Sheriff Fox said. 

The sheriff said he had attended high school with Mr.
Thomas's father, but that he had not yet spoken to any of
the victims' families. 

"You don't know what to say to them," he said. 

Residents
of this town of 500, which is an hour's drive north of
Asheville and home to miners, furniture makers and farmers,
said they could not remember anything so devastating. Even
the 1998 flood of the Cane Creek, which resulted in major
property damage, did not kill anyone, they said. 

"It just breaks your heart," said Kim Hoyle, 34, a former
jailer herself who said she knew most of the victims by
sight or better. "I just get cold chills when I think about
it. I just hope they all knew the Lord before they died." 

The two-story brick jail, connected to a 95-year-old
courthouse by a second-story walkway, was built in 1955
and, like many aging jails in this part of the state,
needed to be replaced, the sheriff said. Officials said it
had been cited for overcrowding as recently as 1997 when it
was used to hold up to 24 inmates, but it was housing 17
inmates on Friday. 

Inmates were allowed to smoke in their cells, but were not
included in regular fire drills, the sheriff said. "You
open a door on some and they'll be gone," he said. 

The jail had no sprinkler system. Cell windows were open to
let fresh air in, but acted like a chimney when the fire
broke out, the sheriff said. 

Though lights-out was not until midnight or 1 a.m., and an
intercom allowing the jailer to communicate with the
inmates was functioning, the jailer on duty did not hear
any shouts or commotion, the sheriff said. 

According to the sheriff's account, the jailer, Diane
Greene, was in an office with the lone female inmate,
Melissa Robinson, 30, who was also a trusty. The two
smelled smoke and Ms. Greene called 911 at 10:05 p.m. The
first firefighters and Deputy Chuck Vines Jr. arrived three
minutes later. 

Deputy Vines, 25, who is the son of Bakersville's mayor,
struggled to retain his composure as he described seeing
the rear of the jail in flames. He said he and a colleague,
Deputy Stacy Hughes, along with one of the first
firefighters on the scene, Mike Smith, all made their way
through the smoke to the first-floor cell. Deputy Hughes
had to race outside for fresh air, while Deputy Vines and
Mr. Smith escorted four conscious inmates outside. Four
others had to be carried out, he said. 

The smoke was so thick that rescuers could not climb the
jail's own stairs to the second floor, Deputy Vines said,
so he and Deputy Hughes tried to lead firefighters through
the courthouse to the jail's upper floor, where seven
inmates were trapped in a group cell. 

But the smoke and heat stopped them, he said. "Stacy and I
and the other firemen without their breathing apparatus
were having to find fresh air, quick," he said. All seven
inmates died. 

Besides Mr. Thomas and Mr. Grindstaff, the dead were:
Edmond Banks, 46; Danny Johnson, 42; Jesse Davis, 27;
Jeremiah Presnell, 20; Jason Boston, 27; and Tywain Neal,
28. 

Two of the surviving inmates were still in the hospital
this afternoon, two had been transferred to another jail,
and five had been released on bond. The jail will be closed
indefinitely. 

Rodney Burleson, 24, said he knew most of the inmates who
died. "Everybody went to the same high school, so everybody
knows who everybody is," he said. 

Mr. Burleson knew Mr. Boston, whose survivors included
three children, one an infant. He said Mr. Boston had been
given the choice between community service and three days
in jail, "and he took the days in jail." 

Joan Conley, the grandmother of Mr. Presnell, said he had
served two weeks of a 60-day sentence for repeatedly
driving without a license. "He never did get a license,
bless his heart," she said. 

Mrs. Conley said Mr. Presnell left behind two daughters,
ages 2 and 3. 

"He'd called me last week and talked to me on the phone,"
she said. "He said, `Mamaw, I just want to know if you're
all right.' I said, `I'm not doing too well.' But I said,
`I want you to get your life straightened out and live for
the Lord.' He said, `Don't you worry, soon as I get out of
here I'm going to be a different person.' 

"And he told me he loved me about three
times."

http://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/05/national/05JAIL.html?ex=1021639007&ei=1&en=2802a3cb3b76380d
